play.title:
THE TRAGEDIE OF
Troylus and Creſsida.

speech.speaker: Prologue
speech.line: In Troy there lyes the Scene: From Iles of Greece
The Princes Orgillous, their high blood chaf’d
Haue to the Port of Athens ſent their ſhippes
Fraught with the miniſters and inſtruments
Of cruell Warre: Sixty and nine that wore
Their Crownets Regall, from th’ Athenian bay
Put forth toward Phrygia, and their vow is made
To ranſacke Troy, within whoſe ſtrong emures
The rauiſh’d Helen, Menelaus Queene,
With wanton Paris ſleepes, and that’s the Quarrell.
To Tenedos they come,
And the deepe-drawing Barke do there diſgorge
Their warlike frautage: now on Dardan Plaines
The freſh and yet vnbruiſed Greekes do pitch
Their braue Pauillions. Priams ſix-gated City,
Dardan and Timbria, Helias, Chetas, Troien,
And Antenonidus with maſsie Staples
And correſponſiue and fulfilling Bolts
Stirre vp the Sonnes of Troy.
Now Expeation tickling skittiſh ſpirits,
On one and other ſide, Troian and Greeke,
Sets all on hazard. And hither am I come,
A Prologue arm’d, but not in confidence
Of Authors pen, or Aors voyce; but ſuited
In like conditions, as our Argument;
To tell you (faire Beholders) that our Play
Leapes ore the vaunt and firſtlings of thoſe broyles,
Beginning in the middle: ſtarting thence away,
To what may be digeſted in a Play:
Like, or finde fault, do as your pleaſures are,
Now good, or bad, ‘tis but the chance of Warre.

speech.speaker: Troylus.
speech.line: Call here my Varlet, Ile vnarme againe.
Why ſhould I warre without the wals of Troy
That finde ſuch cruell battell here within?
Each Troian that is maſter of his heart,
Let him to field, Troylus alas hath none.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Will this geere nere be mended?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: The Greeks are ſtrong, & ſkilful to their ſtrength,
Fierce to their skill, and to their fierceneſſe Valiant:
But I am weaker then a womans teare;
Tamer then ſleepe, fonder then ignorance;
Leſſe valiant then the Virgin in the night,
And skilleſſe as vnprais’d Infancie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well, I haue told you enough of this: For my
part, Ile not meddle nor make no farther. Hee that will
haue a Cake out of the Wheate, muſt needes tarry the
grinding.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Haue I not tarried?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I the grinding; but you muſt tarry the bolting.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Haue I not tarried?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I the boulting; but you muſt tarry the leau’ing,

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Still haue I tarried.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I, to the leauening: but heeres yet in the word
hereafter, the Kneading, the making of the Cake, the
heating of the Ouen, and the Baking; nay, you muſt ſtay
the cooling too, or you may chance to burne your lips.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Patience her ſelfe, what Goddeſſe ere ſhe be,
Doth leſſer blench at ſufferance, then I doe:
At Priams Royall Table doe I ſit;
And when faire Creſſid comes into my thoughts,
So (Traitor) then ſhe comes, when ſhe is thence.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well:
She look’d yeſternight fairer, then euer I ſaw her looke,
Or any woman elſe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I was about to tell thee, when my heart,
As wedged with a ſigh, would riue in twaine,
Leaſt Heor, or my Father ſhould perceiue me:
I haue (as when the Sunne doth light a-ſcorne)
Buried this ſigh, in wrinkle of a ſmile:
But ſorrow, that is couch’d in ſeeming gladneſſe,
Is like that mirth, Fate turnes to ſudden ſadneſſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And her haire were not ſomewhat darker then
Helens, well go too, there were no more compariſon be —
tweene the Women. But for my part ſhe is my Kinſwo —
man, I would not (as they tearme it) praiſe it, but I wold
ſome-body had heard her talke yeſterday as I did: I will
not diſpraiſe your ſiſter Caſſandra’s wit, but— —

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Oh Pandarus! I tell thee Pandarus;
When I doe tell thee, there my hopes lye drown’d:
Reply not in how many Fadomes deepe
They lye indrench’d. I tell thee, I am mad
In Creſſids loue. Thou anſwer’ſt ſhe is Faire,
Powr’ſt in the open Vlcer of my heart,
Her Eyes, her Haire, her Cheeke, her Gate, her Voice,
Handleſt in thy diſcourſe. O that her Hand
(In whoſe compariſon, all whites are Inke)
Writing their owne reproach; to whoſe ſoft ſeizure,
The Cignets Downe is harſh, and ſpirit of Senſe
Hard as the palme of Plough-man. This thou tel’ſt me;
As true thou tel’ſt me, when I ſay I loue her:
But ſaying thus, inſtead of Oyle and Balme,
Thou lai’ſt in euery gaſh that loue hath giuen me,
The Knife that made it.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I ſpeake no more then truth.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Thou do’ſt not ſpeake ſo much.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Faith, Ile not meddle in’t: Let her be as ſhee is,
if ſhe be faire, ‘tis the better for her: and ſhe be not, ſhe
ha’s the mends in her owne hands.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Good Pandarus: How now Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I haue had my Labour for my trauell, ill thought
on of her, and ill thought on of you: Gone betweene and
betweene, but ſmall thankes for my labour.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What art thou angry Pandarus? what with me?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Becauſe ſhe’s Kinne to me, therefore ſhee’s not
ſo faire as Helen, and ſhe were not kin to me, ſhe would
be as faire on Friday, as Helen is on Sunday. But what
care I? I care not and ſhe were a Black-a-Moore, ‘tis all
one to me.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Say I ſhe is not faire?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I doe not care whether you doe or no, Shee’s a
Foole to ſtay behinde her Father: Let her to the Greeks,
and ſo Ile tell her the next time I ſee her: for my part, Ile
meddle nor make no more i’th’ matter.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Sweete Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Pray you ſpeake no more to me, I will leaue all
as I found it, and there an end.

speech.speaker: Tro.
speech.line: Peace you vngracious Clamors, peace rude ſounds,
Fooles on both ſides, Helen muſt needs be faire,
When with your bloud you daily paint her thus.
I cannot fight vpon this Argument:
It is too ſtaru’d a ſubie for my Sword,
But Pandarus: O Gods! How do you plague me?
I cannot come to Creſſid but by Pandar,
And he’s as teachy to be woo’d to woe,
As ſhe is ſtubborne, chaſt, against all ſuite.
Tell me Apollo for thy Daphnes Loue
What Creſſid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India, there ſhe lies, a Pearle,
Between our Ilium, and where ſhee recides
Let it be cald the wild and wandring flood,
Our ſelfe the Merchant, and this ſayling Pandar,
Our doubtfull hope, our conuoy and our Barke.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: How now Prince Troylus?
Wherefore not a field?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Becauſe not there; this womans anſwer ſorts.
For womaniſh it is to be from thence:
What newes Æneas from the field to day?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: That Paris is returned home, and hurt.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: By whom Æneas?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Troylus by Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Let Paris bleed, ‘tis but a ſcar to ſcorne.
Paris is gor’d with Menelaus horne.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Harke what good ſport is out of Towne to day.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Better at home, if would I might were may:
But to the ſport abroad, are you bound thither?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: In all ſwift haſt.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Come goe wee then togither.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Who were thoſe went by?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Queene Hecuba, and Hellen.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: And whether go they?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Vp to the Eaſterne Tower,
Whoſe height commands as ſubie all the vaile,
To ſee the battell: Heor whoſe pacience,
Is as a Vertue fixt, to day was mou’d:
He chides Andromache and ſtrooke his Armorer,
And like as there were husbandry in Warre
Before the Sunne roſe, hee was harneſt lyte,
And to the field goe’s he; where euery flower
Did as a Prophet weepe what it forſaw,
In Heors wrath.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What was his cauſe of anger?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: The noiſe goe’s thus;
There is among the Greekes,
A Lord of Troian blood, Nephew to Heor,
They call him Aiax.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Good; and what of him?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: They ſay he is a very man per ſe and ſtands alone.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So do all men, vnleſſe they are drunke, ſicke, or
haue no legges.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: This man Lady, hath rob’d many beaſts of their
particular additions, he is as valiant as the Lyon, churliſh
as the Beare, ſlow as the Elephant: a man into whom
nature hath ſo crowded humors, that his valour is cruſht
into folly, his folly ſauced with diſcretion: there is no
man hath a vertue, that he hath not a glimpſe of, nor a —
ny man an attaint, but he carries ſome ſtaine of it. He is
melancholy without cauſe, and merry againſt the haire,
hee hath the ioynts of euery thing, but euery thing ſo
out of ioynt, that hee is a gowtie Briareus, many hands
and no vſe; or purblinded Argus, all eyes and no ſight.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: But how ſhould this man that makes me ſmile,
make Heor angry?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: They ſay he yeſterday cop’d Heor in the bat —
tell and ſtroke him downe, the diſdaind & ſhame where —
of, hath euer ſince kept Heor faſting and waking.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Who comes here?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: Madam your Vncle Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Heors a gallant man.

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: As may be in the world Lady.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What’s that? what’s that?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Good morrow Vncle Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Good morrow Cozen Creſſid: what do you talke
of? good morrow Alexander: how do you Cozen? when
were you at Illium?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: This morning Vncle.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What were you talking of when I came? Was
Heor arm’d and gon ere yea came to Illium? Hellen was
not vp? was ſhe?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Heor was gone but Hellen was not vp?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: E’ene ſo; Heor was ſtirring early.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Was he angry?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So he ſaies here.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: True he was ſo; I know the cauſe too, heele lay
about him to day I can tell them that, and there’s Troylus
will not come farre behind him, let them take heede of
Troylus; I can tell them that too.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What is he angry too?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Who Troylus?
Troylus is the better man of the two.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Oh Iupiter; there’s no compariſon.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What not betweene Troylus and Heor? do you
know a man if you ſee him?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: I, if I euer ſaw him before and knew him.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well I ſay Troylus is Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Then you ſay as I ſay,
For I am ſure he is not Heor.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: No not Heor is not Troylus in ſome degrees.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: ‘Tis iuſt, to each of them he is himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Himſelfe? alas poore Troylus I would he were.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So he is.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Condition I had gone bare-foote to India.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: He is not Heor.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Himſelfe? no? hee’s not himſelfe, would a were
himſelfe: well, the Gods are aboue, time muſt friend or
end: well Troylus well, I would my heart were in her bo —
dy; no, Heor is not a better man then Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Excuſe me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: He is elder.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Pardon me, pardon me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Th’ others not come too’t, you ſhall tell me ano —
ther tale when th’ others come too’t: Heor ſhall not
haue his will this yeare.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: He ſhall not neede it if he haue his owne.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nor his qualities.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: No matter.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nor his beautie.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: ‘Twould not become him, his own’s better.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You haue no iudgement Neece; Hellen her ſelfe
ſwore th’ other day, that Troylus for a browne fauour (for
ſo ‘tis I muſt confeſſe) not browne neither.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: No, but browne.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Faith to ſay truth, browne and not browne.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: To ſay the truth, true and not true.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: She prais’d his complexion aboue Paris.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Why Paris hath colour inough.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: So he has.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Then Troylus ſhould haue too much, if ſhe prais’d
him aboue, his complexion is higher then his, he hauing
colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a
praiſe for a good complexion, I had as lieue Hellens gol —
den tongue had commended Troylus for a copper noſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I ſweare to you,
I thinke Hellen loues him better then Paris.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Then ſhee’s a merry Greeke indeed.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nay I am ſure ſhe does, ſhe came to him th’ other
day into the compaſt window, and you know he has not
paſt three or foure haires on his chinne.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Indeed a Tapſters Arithmetique may ſoone
bring his particulars as therein, to a totall.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Why he is very yong, and yet will he within
three pound lift as much as his brother Heor.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Is he is ſo young a man, and ſo old a lifter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: But to prooue to you that Hellen loues him, ſhe
came and puts me her white hand to his clouen chin.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Iuno haue mercy, how came it clouen?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Why, you know ‘tis dimpled,
I thinke his ſmyling becomes him better then any man
in all Phrigia.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Oh he ſmiles valiantly.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Dooes hee not?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Oh yes, and ‘twere a clow’d in Autumne.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Why go to then, but to proue to you that Hellen
loues Troylus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Troylus wil ſtand to thee
Proofe, if youle prooue it ſo.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Troylus? why he eſteemes her no more then I e —
ſteeme an addle egge.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: If you loue an addle egge as well as you loue an
idle head, you would eate chickens i’th’ ſhell.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I cannot chuſe but laugh to thinke how ſhe tick —
led his chin, indeed ſhee has a maruel’s white hand I muſt
needs confeſſe.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Without the racke.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And ſhee takes vpon her to ſpie a white haire on
his chinne.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Alas poore chin? many a wart is richer.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: But there was ſuch laughing, Queene Hecuba
laught that her eyes ran ore.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: With Milſtones.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And Caſſandra laught.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: But there was more temperate fire vnder the pot
of her eyes: did her eyes run ore too?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: And Heor laught.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: At what was all this laughing?

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Marry at the white haire that Hellen ſpied on
Troylus chin.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: And t’had beene a greene haire, I ſhould haue
laught too.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: They laught not ſo much at the haire, as at his
pretty answere.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What was his answere?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Quoth ſhee, heere’s but two and fifty haires on
your chinne; and one of them is white.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: This is her queſtion.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: That’s true, make no queſtion of that, two and
fiftie haires quoth hee, and one white, that white haire is
my Father, and all the reſt are his Sonnes. Iupiter quoth
ſhe, which of theſe haires is Paris my husband? The for —
ked one quoth he, pluckt out and giue it him: but there
was ſuch laughing, and Hellen ſo bluſht, and Paris ſo
chaft, and all the reſt ſo laught, that it paſt.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So let it now,
For it has beene a great while going by.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well Cozen,
I told you a thing yeſterday, think on’t.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: So I does.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Ile be ſworne ‘tis true, he will weepe you
an ‘twere a man borne in Aprill.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: And Ile ſpring vp in his teares, an ‘twere a nettle
againſt May.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Harke they are comming from the field, ſhal we
ſtand vp here and ſee them, as they paſſe toward Illium,
good Neece do, ſweet Neece Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: At your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Heere, heere, here’s an excellent place, heere we
may ſee moſt brauely, Ile tel you them all by their names,
as they paſſe by, but marke Troylus aboue the reſt.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Speake not ſo low’d.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That’s Æneas, is not that a braue man, hee’s one
of the flowers of Troy I can you, marke Troylus, you
ſhal ſee anon.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Who’s that?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That’s Antenor, he has a ſhrow’d wit I can tell
you, and hee’s a man good inough, hee’s one o’th ſoun —
deſt iudgement in Troy whoſoeuer, and a proper man of
perſon: when comes Troylus? Ile ſhew you Troylus anon,
if hee ſee me, you ſhall ſee him nod at me.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Will he giue you the nod?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You ſhall ſee.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: If he do, the rich ſhall haue, more.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That’s Heor, that, that looke you, that there’s a
fellow. Goe thy way Heor, there’s a braue man Neece,
O braue Heor! Looke how hee lookes? there’s a coun —
tenance; iſt not a braue man?

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: O braue man!

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is a not? It dooes a mans heart good, looke you
what hacks are on his Helmet, looke you yonder, do you
ſee? Looke you there? There’s no ieſting, laying on, tak’t
off, who ill as they ſay, there be hacks.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Be thoſe with Swords?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Swords, any thing he cares not, and the diuell
come to him, it’s all one, by Gods lid it dooes ones heart
good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris: looke
yee yonder Neece, iſt not a gallant man to, iſt not? Why
this is braue now: who ſaid he came hurt home to day?
Hee’s not hurt, why this will do Hellens heart good
now, ha? Would I could ſee Troylus now, you ſhall Troy-
lus anon.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Whoſe that?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: That’s Hellenus, I maruell where Troylus is, that’s
Helenus, I thinke he went not forth to day: that’s Hel-
lenus.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Can Hellenus fight Vncle?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Hellenus no: yes heele fight indifferent, well, I
maruell where Troylus is; harke, do you not haere the
people crie Troylus? Hellenus is a Prieſt.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: What ſneaking fellow comes yonder?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Where? Yonder? That’s Dœphobus. ‘Tis Troy-
lus! Ther’s a man Neece, hem? Braue Troylus the Prince
of Chiualrie.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Peace, for ſhame peace.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Marke him, not him: O braue Troylus: looke
well vpon him Neece, looke you how his Sword is blou —
died, and his Helme more hackt then Heors, and how he
lookes, and how he goes. O admirable youth! he ne’re
ſaw three and twenty. Go thy way Troylus, go thy way,
had I a ſiſter were a Grace, or a daughter a Goddeſſe, hee
ſhould take his choice. O admirable man! Paris? Paris
is durt to him, and I warrant, Helen to change, would
giue money to boot.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Heere come more.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Aſſes, fooles, dolts, chaffe and bran, chaffe and
bran; porredge after meat. I could liue and dye i’th’ eyes
of Troylus. Ne’re looke, ne’re looke; the Eagles are gon,
Crowes and Dawes, Crowes and Dawes: I had rather be
ſuch a man as Troylus, then Agamemnon, and all Greece.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: There is among the Greekes Achilles, a better
man then Troylus.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Achilles? a Dray-man, a Porter, a very Camell.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Well, well.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well, well? Why haue you any diſcretion? haue
you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth,
beauty, good ſhape, diſcourſe, manhood, learning, gen —
tleneſſe, vertue, youth, liberality, and ſo forth: the Spice,
and ſalt that ſeaſons a man?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I, a minc’d man, and then to be bak’d with no Date
in the pye, for then the mans dates out.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You are ſuch another woman, one knowes not
at what ward you lye.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Vpon my backe, to defend my belly; vpon my
wit, to defend my wiles; vppon my ſecrecy, to defend
mine honeſty; my Maske, to defend my beauty, and you
to defend all theſe: and all theſe wardes I lye at, at a
thouſand watches.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Say one of your watches.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Nay Ile watch you for that, and that’s one of
the cheefeſt of them too: If I cannot ward what I would
not haue hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the
blow, vnleſſe it ſwell paſt hiding, and then it’s paſt wat —
ching.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You are ſuch another.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Sir, my Lord would inſtantly ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Where?

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: At your owne houſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Good Boy tell him I come, I doubt he bee hurt.
Fare ye well good Neece.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Adieu Vnkle.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Ile be with you Neece by and by.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: To bring Vnkle.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I, a token from Troylus.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: By the ſame token, you are a Bawd.
Words, vowes, gifts, teares, & loues full ſacrifice,
He offers in anothers enterpriſe:
But more in Troylus thouſand fold I ſee,
Then in the glaſſe of Pandar’s praiſe may be;
Yet hold I off. Women are Angels wooing,
Things won are done, ioyes ſoule lyes in the dooing:
That ſhe belou’d, knowes nought, that knowes not this;
Men prize the thing vngain’d, more then it is.
That ſhe was neuer yet, that euer knew
Loue got ſo ſweet, as when deſire did ſue:
Therefore this maxime out of loue I teach;
That though my hearts Contents firme loue doth beare,
Nothing of that ſhall from mine eyes appeare.

scene.stagedir: Senet. Enter Agamemnon, Neſtor, Vlyſſes, Diomedes, Menelaus, with others.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Princes:
What greefe hath ſet the Iaundies on your cheekes?
The ample propoſition that hope makes
In all deſignes, begun on earth below
Fayles in the promiſt largeneſſe: checkes and diſaſters
Grow in the veines of aions higheſt rear’d.
As knots by the conflux of meeting ſap,
Infe the ſound Pine, and diuerts his Graine
Tortiue and erant from his courſe of growth.
Nor Princes, is it matter new to vs,
That we come ſhort of our ſuppoſe ſo farre,
That after ſeuen yeares ſiege, yet Troy walles ſtand,
Sith euery aion that hath gone before,
Whereof we haue Record, Triall did draw
Bias and thwart, not anſwering the ayme:
And that vnbodied figure of the thought
That gaue’t ſurmiſed ſhape. Why then (you Princes)
Do you with cheekes abaſh’d, behold our workes,
And thinke them ſhame, which are (indeed) nought elſe
But the protraiue trials of great loue,
To finde perſiſtiue conſtancie in men?
The fineneſſe of which Mettall is not found
In Fortunes loue: for then, the Bold and Coward,
The Wiſe and Foole, the Artiſt and vn-read,
The hard and ſoft, ſeeme all affin’d, and kin.
But in the Winde and Tempeſt of her frowne,
Diſtinion with a lowd and powrefull fan,
Puffing at all, winnowes the light away;
And what hath maſſe, or matter by it ſelfe,
Lies rich in Vertue, and vnmingled.

speech.speaker: Nestor.
speech.line: With due Obſeruance of thy godly ſeat,
Great Agamemnon, Neſtor ſhall apply
Thy lateſt words.
In the reproofe of Chance,
Lies the true proofe of men: The Sea being ſmooth,
How many ſhallow bauble Boates dare ſaile
Vpon her patient breſt, making their way
With thoſe of Nobler bulke?
But let the Ruffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Thetis, and anon behold
The ſtrong ribb’d Barke through liquid Mountaines cut,
Bounding betweene the two moyſt Elements
Like Perſeus Horſe. Where’s then the ſawcy Boate,
Whoſe weake vntimber’d ſides but euen now
Co-riual’d Greatneſſe? Either to harbour fled,
Or made a Toſte for Neptune. Euen ſo,
Doth valours ſhew, and valours worth diuide
In ſtormes of Fortune.
For, in her ray and brightneſſe,
The Heard hath more annoyance by the Brieze
Then by the Tyger: But, when the ſplitting winde
Makes flexible the knees of knotted Oakes,
And Flies fled vnder ſhade, why then
The thing of Courage,
As rowz’d with rage, with rage doth ſympathize,
And with an accent tun’d in ſelfe-ſame key,
Retyres to chiding Fortune.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Agamemnon:
Thou great Commander, Nerue, and Bone of Greece,
Heart of our Numbers, ſoule, and onely ſpirit,
In whom the tempers, and the mindes of all
Should be ſhut vp: Heare what Vlyſſes ſpeakes,
Beſides the applauſe and approbation
The which moſt mighty for thy place and ſway,
And thou moſt reuerend for thy ſtretcht-out life,
I giue to both your ſpeeches: which were ſuch,
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece
Should hold vp high in Braſſe: and ſuch againe
As venerable Neſtor (hatch’d in Siluer)
Should with a bond of ayre, ſtrong as the Axletree
In which the Heauens ride, knit all Greekes eares
To his experienc’d tongue: yet let it pleaſe both
(Thou Great, and Wiſe) to heare Vlyſſes ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Speak Prince of Ithaca, and be’t of leſſe expe:
That matter needleſſe of importleſſe burthen
Diuide thy lips; then we are confident
When ranke Therſites opes his Maſticke iawes,
We ſhall heare Muſicke, Wit, and Oracle.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Troy yet vpon his baſis had bene downe,
And the great Heors ſword had lack’d a Maſter
But for theſe inſtances.
The ſpecialty of Rule hath beene negleed;
And looke how many Grecian Tents do ſtand
Hollow vpon this Plaine, ſo many hollow Faions.
When that the Generall is not like the Hiue,
To whom the Forragers ſhall all repaire,
What Hony is expeed? Degree being vizarded,
Th’ vnworthieſt ſhewes as fairely in the Maske.
The Heauens themſelues, the Planets, and this Center,
Obſerue degree, priority, and place,
Inſiſture, courſe, proportion, ſeaſon, forme,
Office, and cuſtome, in all line of Order:
And therefore is the glorious Planet Sol
In noble eminence, enthron’d, and ſphear’d
Amid’ſt the other, whoſe med’cinable eye
Corres the ill Aſpes of Planets euill,
And poſtes like the Command’ment of a King,
Sans checke, to good and bad. But when the Planets
In euill mixture to diſorder wander,
What Plagues, and what portents, what mutiny?
What raging of the Sea? ſhaking of Earth?
Commotion in the Windes? Frights, changes, horrors,
Diuert, and cracke, rend and deracinate
The vnity, and married calme of States
Quite from their fixure? O, when Degree is ſhak’d,
(Which is the Ladder to all high deſignes)
The enterprize is ſicke. How could Communities,
Degrees in Schooles, and Brother-hoods in Cities,
Peacefull Commerce from diuidable ſhores,
The primogenitiue, and due of Byrth,
Prerogatiue of Age, Crownes, Scepters, Lawrels,
(But by Degree) ſtand in Authentique place?
Take but Degree away, vn-tune that ſtring,
And hearke what Diſcord followes: each thing meetes
In meere oppugnancie. The bounded Waters,
Should lift their boſomes higher then the Shores,
And make a ſoppe of all this ſolid Globe:
Strength ſhould be Lord of imbecility,
And the rude Sonne ſhould ſtrike his Father dead:
Force ſhould be right, or rather, right and wrong,
(Betweene whoſe endleſſe iarre, Iuſtice recides)
Should looſe her names, and ſo ſhould Iuſtice too.
Then euery thing includes it ſelfe in Power,
Power into Will, Will into Appetite,
And Appetite (an vniuerſall Wolfe,
So doubly ſeconded with Will, and Power)
Muſt make perforce an vniuerſall prey,
And laſt, eate vp himſelfe.
Great Agamemnon:
This Chaos, when Degree is ſuffocate,
Followes the choaking:
And this negleion of Degree, is it
That by a pace goes backward in a purpoſe
It hath to climbe. The Generall’s diſdain’d
By him one ſtep below; he, by the next,
That next, by him beneath: ſo euery ſtep
Exampled by the firſt pace that is ſicke
Of his Superiour, growes to an enuious Feauer
Of pale, and bloodleſſe Emulation.
And ‘tis this Feauer that keepes Troy on foote,
Not her owne ſinewes. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weakneſſe liues, not in her ſtrength.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Moſt wiſely hath Vlyſſes heere diſcouer’d
The Feauer, whereof all our power is ſicke.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: The Nature of the ſickneſſe found (Vlyſſes)
What is the remedie?

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: The great Achilles, whom Opinion crownes,
The ſinew, and the fore-hand of our Hoſte,
Hauing his eare full of his ayery Fame,
Growes dainty of his worth, and in his Tent
Lyes mocking our deſignes. With him, Patroclus,
Vpon a lazie Bed, the liue-long day
Breakes ſcurrill Ieſts,
And with ridiculous and aukward aion,
(Which Slanderer, he imitation call’s)
He Pageants vs. Sometime great Agamemnon,
Thy topleſſe deputation he puts on;
And like a ſtrutting Player, whoſe conceit
Lies in his Ham-ſtring, and doth thinke it rich
To heare the woodden Dialogue and ſound
‘Twixt his ſtretcht footing, and the Scaffolage,
Such to be pittied, and ore-reſted ſeeming
He as thy Greatneſſe in: and when he ſpeakes,
‘Tis like a Chime a mending. With tearmes vnſquar’d,
Which from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropt,
Would ſeemes Hyperboles. At this fuſty ſtuffe,
The large Achilles (on his preſt-bed lolling)
From his deepe Cheſt, laughes out a lowd applauſe,
Cries excellent, ‘tis Agamemnon iuſt.
Now play me Neſtor; hum, and ſtroke thy Beard
As he, being dreſt to ſome Oration:
That’s done, as neere as the extreameſt ends
Of paralels; as like, as Vulcan and his wife,
Yet god Achilles ſtill cries excellent,
‘Tis Neſtor right. Now play him (me) Patroclus,
Arming to anſwer in a night-Alarme,
And then (forſooth) the faint defes of Age
Must be the Scene of myrth, to cough, and ſpit,
And with a palſie fumbling on his Gorget,
Shake in and out the Riuet: and at this ſport
Sir Valour dies; cries, O enough Patroclus,
Or, giue me ribs of Steele, I ſhall ſplit all
In pleaſure of my Spleene. And in this faſhion,
All our abilities, gifts, natures, ſhapes,
Seuerals and generals of grace exa,
Atchieuments, plots, orders, preuentions,
Excitements to the field, or ſpeech for truce,
Succeſſe or loſſe, what is, or is not, ſerues
As ſtuffe for theſe two, to make paradoxes.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: And in the imitation of theſe twaine,
Who (as Vlyſſes ſayes) Opinion crownes
With an Imperiall voyce, many are infe:
Aiax is growne ſelfe-will’d, and beares his head
In ſuch a reyne, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles, and keepes his Tent like him;
Makes faious Feaſts, railes on our ſtate of Warre
Bold as an Oracle, and ſets Therſites
A ſlaue, whoſe Gall coines ſlanders like a Mint,
To match vs in compariſons with durt,
To weaken and diſcredit our expoſure,
How ranke ſoeuer rounded in with danger.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: They taxe our policy, and call it Cowardice,
Count Wiſedome as no member of the Warre,
Fore-ſtall preſcience, and eſteeme no ae
But that of hand: The ſtill and mentall parts,
That do contriue how many hands ſhall ſtrike
When fitneſſe call them on, and know by meaſure
Of their obſeruant toyle, the Enemies waight,
Why this hath not a fingers dignity:
They call this Bed-worke, Mapp’ry, Cloſſet-Warre:
So that the Ramme that batters downe the wall,
For the great ſwing and rudeneſſe of his poize,
They place before his hand that made the Engine,
Or thoſe that with the fineneſſe of their ſoules,
By Reaſon guide his execution.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Let this be granted, and Achilles horſe
Makes many Thetis ſonnes.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What Trumpet? Looke Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: From Troy.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What would you ‘fore our Tent?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Is this great Agamemnons Tent, I pray you?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Euen this.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: May one that is a Herald, and a Prince,
Do a faire meſſage to his Kingly eares?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: With ſurety ſtronger then Achilles arme,
‘Fore all the Greekiſh heads, which with one voyce
Call Agamemnon Head and Generall.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Faire leaue, and large ſecurity. How may
A ſtranger to thoſe moſt Imperial lookes,
Know them from eyes of other Mortals?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: How?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: I: I aske, that I might waken reuerence,
And on the cheeke be ready with a bluſh
Modeſt as morning, when ſhe coldly eyes
The youthfull Phœbus:
Which is that God in office guiding men?
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: This Troyan ſcornes vs, or the men of Troy
Are ceremonious Courtiers.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Courtiers as free, as debonnaire; vnarm’d,
As bending Angels; that’s their Fame, in peace;
But when they would ſeeme Souldiers, they haue galles,
Good armes, ſtrong ioynts, true ſwords, & Ioues accord,
Nothing ſo full of heart. But peace Æneas,
Peace Troyan, lay thy finger on thy lips,
The worthineſſe of praiſe diſtaines his worth:
If that he prais’d himſelfe, bring the praiſe forth.
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath Fame blowes, that praiſe ſole pure tranſcéds.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Sir, you of Troy, call you your ſelfe Æneas?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: I Greeke, that is my name.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What’s your affayre I pray you?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Sir pardon, ‘tis for Agamemnons eares.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: He heares nought priuatly
That comes from Troy.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Nor I from Troy come not to whiſper him,
I bring a Trumpet to awake his eare,
To ſet his ſence on the attentiue bent,
And then to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Speake frankely as the winde,
It is not Agamemnons ſleeping houre;
That thou ſhalt know Troyan he is awake,
He tels thee ſo himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Trumpet blow loud,
Send thy Braſſe voyce through all theſe lazie Tents,
And euery Greeke of mettle, let him know,
What Troy meanes fairely, ſhall be ſpoke alowd.
We haue great Agamemnon heere in Troy,
A Prince call’d Heor, Priam is his Father:
Who in this dull and long-continew’d Truce
Is ruſty growne. He bad me take a Trumpet,
And to this purpoſe ſpeake: Kings, Princes, Lords,
If there be one among’ſt the fayr’ſt of Greece,
That holds his Honor higher then his eaſe,
That ſeekes his praiſe, more then he feares his perill,
That knowes his Valour, and knowes not his feare,
That loues his Miſtris more then in confeſſion,
(With truant vowes to her owne lips he loues)
And dare avow her Beauty, and her Worth,
In other armes then hers: to him this Challenge.
Heor, in view of Troyans, and of Greekes,
Shall make it good, or do his beſt to do it.
He hath a Lady, wiſer, fairer, truer,
Then euer Greeke did compaſſe in his armes,
And will to morrow with his Trumpet call,
Midway betweene your Tents, and walles of Troy,
To rowze a Grecian that is true in loue.
If any come, Heor ſhal honour him:
If none, hee’l ſay in Troy when he retyres,
The Grecian Dames are ſun-burnt, and not worth
The ſplinter of a Lance: Euen ſo much.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: This ſhall be told our Louers Lord Æneas,
If none of them haue ſoule in ſuch a kinde,
We left them all at home: But we are Souldiers,
And may that Souldier a meere recreant proue,
That meanes not, hath not, or is not in loue:
If then one is, or hath, or meanes to be,
That one meets Heor; if none elſe, Ile be he.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Tell him of Neſtor, one that was a man
When Heors Grandſire ſuckt: he is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian mould,
One Noble man, that hath one ſpark of fire
To anſwer for his Loue; tell him from me,
Ile hide my Siluer beard in a Gold Beauer,
And in my Vantbrace put this wither’d brawne,
And meeting him, wil tell him, that my Lady
Was fayrer then his Grandame, and as chaſte
As may be in the world: his youth in flood,
Ile pawne this truth with my three drops of blood.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Now heauens forbid ſuch ſcarſitie of youth.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Faire Lord Æneas,
Let me touch your hand:
To our Pauillion ſhal I leade you firſt:
Achilles ſhall haue word of this intent,
So ſhall each Lord of Greece from Tent to Tent:
Your ſelfe ſhall Feaſt with vs before you goe,
And finde the welcome of a Noble Foe.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Nestor.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: What ſayes Vlyſſes?

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: I haue a young conception in my braine,
Be you my time to bring it to ſome ſhape.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: What is’t?

speech.speaker: Vlyſſes.
speech.line: This ‘tis:
Blunt wedges riue hard knots: the ſeeded Pride
That hath to this maturity blowne vp
In ranke Achilles, muſt or now be cropt,
Or ſhedding breed a Nurſery of like euil
To ouer-bulke vs all.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Wel, and how?

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: This challenge that the gallant Heor ſends,
How euer it is ſpred in general name,
Relates in purpoſe onely to Achilles.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: The purpoſe is perſpicuous euen as ſubſtance,
Whoſe groſſeneſſe little charraers ſumme vp,
And in the publication make no ſtraine,
But that Achilles, were his braine as barren
As bankes of Lybia, though ( Apollo knowes)
‘Tis dry enough, wil with great ſpeede of iudgement,
I, with celerity, finde Heors purpoſe
Pointing on him.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: And wake him to the anſwer, thinke you?

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Yes, ‘tis moſt meet; who may you elſe oppoſe
That can from Heor bring his Honor off,
If not Achilles; though’t be a ſportfull Combate,
Yet in this triall, much opinion dwels.
For heere the Troyans taſte our deer’ſt repute
With their fin’ſt Pallate: and truſt to me Vlyſſes,
Our imputation ſhall be oddely poiz’d
In this wilde aion. For the ſucceſſe
(Although particular) ſhall giue a ſcantling
Of good or bad, vnto the Generall:
And in ſuch Indexes, although ſmall prickes
To their ſubſequent Volumes, there is ſeene
The baby figure of the Gyant-maſſe
Of things to come at large. It is ſuppos’d,
He that meets Heor, iſſues from our choyſe;
And choiſe being mutuall ae of all our ſoules,
Makes Merit her eleion, and doth boyle
As ‘twere, from forth vs all: a man diſtill’d
Out of our Vertues; who miſcarrying,
What heart from hence receyues the conqu’ring part
To ſteele a ſtrong opinion to themſelues,
Which entertain’d, Limbes are in his inſtruments,
In no leſſe working, then are Swords and Bowes
Direiue by the Limbes.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Giue pardon to my ſpeech:
Therefore ‘tis meet Achilles meet not Heor:
Let vs (like Merchants) ſhew our fowleſt Wares,
And thinke perchance they’l ſell: If not,
The luſter of the better yet to ſhew,
Shall ſhew the better. Do not conſent,
That euer Heor and Achilles meete:
For both our Honour, and our Shame in this,
Are dogg’d with two ſtrange Followers.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: I ſee them not with my old eies: what are they?

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: What glory our Achilles ſhares from Heor,
(Were he not proud) we all ſhould weare with him:
But he already is too inſolent,
And we were better parch in Affricke Sunne,
Then in the pride and ſalt ſcorne of his eyes
Should he ſcape Heor faire. If he were foyld,
Why then we did our maine opinion cruſh
In taint of our beſt man. No, make a Lott’ry,
And by deuice let blockiſh Aiax draw
The ſort to fight with Heor: Among our ſelues,
Giue him allowance as the worthier man,
For that will phyſicke the great Myrmidon
Who broyles in lowd applauſe, and make him fall
His Creſt, that prouder then blew Iris bends.
If the dull brainleſſe Aiax come ſafe off,
Wee’l dreſſe him vp in voyces: if he faile,
Yet go we vnder our opinion ſtill,
That we haue better men. But hit or miſſe,
Our proies life this ſhape of ſence aſſumes,
Aiax imploy’d, pluckes downe Achilles Plumes.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Now Vlyſſes, I begin to relliſh thy aduice,
And I wil giue a taſte of it forthwith
To Agamemnon, go we to him ſtraight:
Two Curres ſhal tame each other, Pride alone
Muſt tarre the Maſtiffes on, as ‘twere their bone.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Therſites?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon, how if he had Biles (ful) all ouer
generally.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Therſites?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: And thoſe Byles did runne, ſay ſo; did not the
General run, were not that a botchy core?

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Dogge.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Then there would come ſome matter from him:
I ſee none now.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thou Bitch-Wolfes-Sonne, canſt ӳ not heare?
Feele then.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: The plague of Greece vpon thee thou Mungrel
beefe-witted Lord.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Speake then you whinid’ſt leauen ſpeake, I will
beate thee into handſomneſſe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſhal ſooner rayle thee into wit and holineſſe:
but I thinke thy Horſe wil ſooner con an Oration, then ӳ
learn a prayer without booke: Thou canſt ſtrike, canſt
thou? A red Murren o’thy Iades trickes.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Toads ſtoole, learne me the Proclamation.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Doeſt thou thinke I haue no ſence thou ſtrik’ſt me thus?

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: The Proclamation.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thou art proclaim’d a foole, I thinke.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Do not Porpentine, do not; my fingers itch.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I would thou didſt itch from head to foot, and
I had the ſcratching of thee, I would make thee the loth —
ſom’st ſcab in Greece.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I ſay the Proclamation.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thou grumbleſt & raileſt euery houre on A —
chilles, and thou art as ful of enuy at his greatnes, as Cer —
berus is at Proſerpina’s beauty. I, that thou barkſt at him.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Miſtreſſe Therſites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thou ſhould’ſt ſtrike him.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Coblofe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: He would pun thee into ſhiuers with his fiſt, as
a Sailor breakes a bisket.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: You horſon Curre.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Do, do.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thou ſtoole for a Witch.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I, do, do, thou ſodden-witted Lord: thou haſt
no more braine then I haue in mine elbows: An Aſinico
may tutor thee. Thou ſcuruy valiant Aſſe, thou art heere
but to threſh Troyans, and thou art bought and ſolde a —
mong thoſe of any wit, like a Barbarian ſlaue. If thou vſe
to beat me, I wil begin at thy heele, and tel what thou art
by inches, thou thing of no bowels thou.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: You dogge.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: You ſcuruy Lord.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: You Curre.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Mars his Ideot: do rudenes, do Camell, do, do.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Why how now Aiax? wherefore do you this?
How now Therſites? what’s the matter man?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: You ſee him there, do you?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I, what’s the matter.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Nay looke vpon him.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: So I do: what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Nay but regard him well.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Well, why I do ſo.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: But yet you looke not well vpon him: for who
ſome euer you take him to be, he is Aiax.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I know that foole.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I, but that foole knowes not himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Therefore I beate thee.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he vtters: his
euaſions haue eares thus long. I haue bobb’d his Braine
more then he has beate my bones: I will buy nine Spar —
rowes for a peny, and his Piamater is not worth the ninth
part of a Sparrow. This Lord ( Achilles) Aiax who wears
his wit in his belly, and his guttes in his head, Ile tell you
what I ſay of him.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſay this Aiax— —

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Nay good Aiax.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Has not ſo much wit.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Nay, I muſt hold you.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: As will ſtop the eye of Helens Needle, for whom
he comes to fight.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Peace foole.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I would haue peace and quietnes, but the foole
will not: he there, that he, looke you there.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: O thou damn’d Curre, I ſhall— —

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Will you ſet your wit to a Fooles.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No I warrant you, for a fooles will ſhame it.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Good words Therſites.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What’s the quarrell?

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I bad thee vile Owle, goe learne me the tenure
of the Proclamation, and he rayles vpon me.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſerue thee not.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Well, go too, go too.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I ſerue heere voluntary.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Your laſt ſeruice was ſufferance, ‘twas not vo —
luntary, no man is beaten voluntary: Aiax was heere the
voluntary, and you as vnder an Impreſſe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: E’ne ſo, a great deale of your wit too lies in your
ſinnewes, or elſe there be Liars. Heor ſhall haue a great
catch, if he knocke out either of your braines, he were as
good cracke a fuſtie nut with no kernell.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What with me to Therſites?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: There’s Vlyſſes, and old Neſtor, whoſe Wit was
mouldy ere their Grandſires had nails on their toes, yoke
you like draft-Oxen, and make you plough vp the warre.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What? what?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Yes good ſooth, to Achilles, to Aiax, to— —

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I ſhall cut out your tongue.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: ‘Tis no matter, I ſhall ſpeake as much as thou
afterwards.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: No more words Therſites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I will hold my peace when Achilles Brooch bids
me, ſhall I?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: There’s for you Patroclus.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I will ſee you hang’d like Clotpoles ere I come
any more to your Tents; I will keepe where there is wit
ſtirring, and leaue the faion of fooles.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: A good riddance.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Marry this Sir is proclaim’d through al our hoſt,
That Heor by the fift houre of the Sunne,
Will with a Trumpet, ‘twixt our Tents and Troy
To morrow morning call ſome Knight to Armes,
That hath a ſtomacke, and ſuch a one that dare
Maintaine I know not what: ‘tis traſh. Farewell.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Farewell? who ſhall anſwer him?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I know not, ‘tis put to Lottry: otherwiſe
He knew his man.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: O meaning you, I wil go learne more of it.

scene.stagedir: Enter Priam, Heor, Troylus, Paris and Helenus.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: After ſo many houres, liues, ſpeeches ſpent,
Thus once againe ſayes Neſtor from the Greekes,
Deliuer Helen, and all damage elſe
(As honour, loſſe of time, trauaile, expence,
Wounds, friends, and what els deere that is conſum’d
In hot digeſtion of this comorant Warre)
Shall be ſtroke off. Heor, what ſay you too’t.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Though no man leſſer feares the Greeks then I,
As farre as touches my particular: yet dread Priam,
There is no Lady of more ſofter bowels,
More ſpungie, to ſucke in the ſenſe of Feare,
More ready to cry out, who knowes what followes
Then Heor is: the wound of peace is ſurety.
Surety ſecure: but modeſt Doubt is cal’d
The Beacon of the wiſe: the tent that ſearches
To’th’ bottome of the worſt. Let Helen go,
Since the firſt ſword was drawne about this queſtion,
Euery tythe ſoule ‘mongſt many thouſand diſmes,
Hath bin as deere as Helen: I meane of ours:
If we haue loſt ſo many tenths of ours
To guard a thing not ours, nor worth to vs
(Had it our name) the valew of one ten;
What merit’s in that reaſon which denies
The yeelding of her vp.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Fie, fie, my Brother;
Weigh you the worth and honour of a King
(So great as our dread Father) in a Scale
Of common Ounces? Wil you with Counters ſumme
The paſt proportion of his infinite,
And buckle in a waſte moſt fathomleſſe,
With ſpannes and inches ſo diminutiue,
As feares and reaſons? Fie for godly ſhame?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: No maruel though you bite ſo ſharp at reaſons,
You are ſo empty of them, ſhould not our Father
Beare the great ſway of his affayres with reaſons,
Becauſe your ſpeech hath none that tels him ſo.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You are for dreames & ſlumbers brother Prieſt
You furre your gloues with reaſon: here are your reaſons
You know an enemy intends you harme,
You know, a ſword imploy’d is perillous,
And reaſon flyes the obie of all harme.
Who maruels then when Helenus beholds
A Grecian and his ſword, if he do ſet
The very wings of reaſon to his heeles:
Or like a Starre diſorb’d. Nay, if we talke of Reaſon,
And flye like chidden Mercurie from Ioue,
Let’s ſhut our gates and ſleepe: Manhood and Honor
Should haue hard hearts, wold they but fat their thoghts
With this cramm’d reaſon: reaſon and reſpe,
Makes Liuers pale, and luſtyhood deie.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Brother, ſhe is not worth
What ſhe doth coſt the holding.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What’s aught, but as ‘tis valew’d?

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: But value dwels not in particular will,
It holds his eſtimate and dignitie
As well, wherein ‘tis precious of it ſelfe,
As in the prizer: ‘Tis made Idolatrie,
To make the ſeruice greater then the God,
And the will dotes that is inclineable
To what infeiouſly it ſelfe affes,
Without ſome image of th’ affeed merit.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I take to day a Wife, and my eleion
Is led on in the condu of my Will;
My Will enkindled by mine eyes and eares,
Two traded Pylots ‘twixt the dangerous ſhores
Of Will, and Iudgement. How may I auoyde
(Although my will diſtaste what it eleed)
The Wife I choſe, there can be no euaſion
To blench from this, and to ſtand firme by honour.
We turne not backe the Silkes vpon the Merchant
When we haue ſpoyl’d them; nor the remainder Viands
We do not throw in vnreſpeiue ſame,
Becauſe we now are full. It was thought meete
Paris ſhould do ſome vengeance on the Greekes;
Your breath of full conſent bellied his Sailes,
The Seas and Windes (old Wranglers) tooke a Truce,
And did him ſeruice; he touch’d the Ports deſir’d,
And for an old Aunt whom the Greekes held Captiue,
He brought a Grecian Queen, whoſe youth & freſhneſſe
Wrinkles Apolloes, and makes ſtale the morning.
Why keepe we her? the Grecians keepe our Aunt:
Is ſhe worth keeping? Why ſhe is a Pearle,
Whoſe price hath launch’d aboue a thouſand Ships,
And turn’d Crown’d Kings to Merchants.
If you’l auouch, ‘twas wiſedome Paris went,
(As you muſt needs, for you all cride, Go, go:)
If you’l confeſſe, he brought home Noble prize,
(As you muſt needs) for you all clapt your hands,
And cride ineſtimable; why do you now
The iſſue of your proper Wiſedomes rate,
And do a deed that Fortune neuer did?
Begger the eſtimation which you priz’d,
Richer then Sea and Land? O Theft moſt baſe!
That we haue ſtolne what we do feare to keepe.
But Theeues vnworthy of a thing ſo ſtolne,
That in their Country did them that diſgrace,
We feare to warrant in our Natiue place.

scene.stagedir: Enter Caſſandra with her haire about her eares.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Cry Troyans, cry.

speech.speaker: Priam.
speech.line: What noyſe? what ſhreeke is this?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: ‘Tis our mad ſiſter, I do know her voyce.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Cry Troyans.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: It is Caſſandra.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Cry Troyans cry; lend me ten thouſand eyes,
And I will fill them with Propheticke teares.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Peace ſiſter, peace.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Virgins, and Boyes; mid-age & wrinkled old,
Soft infancie, that nothing can but cry,
Adde to my clamour: let vs pay betimes
A moity of that maſſe of moane to come.
Cry Troyans cry, praiſe your eyes with teares,
Troy muſt not be, nor goodly Illion ſtand,
Our fire-brand Brother Paris burnes vs all.
Cry Troyans cry, a Helen and a woe;
Cry, cry, Troy burnes, or elſe let Helen goe.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Now youthfull Troylus, do not theſe hie ſtrains
Of diuination in our Siſter, worke
Some touches of remorſe? Or is your bloud
So madly hot, that no diſcourſe of reaſon,
Nor feare of bad ſucceſſe in a bad cauſe,
Can qualifie the ſame?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Why Brother Heor,
We may not thinke the iuſtneſſe of each ae
Such, and no other then euent doth forme it,
Nor once deie the courage of our mindes;
Becauſe Caſſandra’s mad, her brainſicke raptures
Cannot diſtaſte the goodneſſe of a quarrell,
Which hath our ſeuerall Honours all engag’d
To make it gracious. For my priuate part,
I am no more touch’d, then all Priams ſonnes,
And Ioue forbid there ſhould be done among’ſt vs
Such things as might offend the weakeſt ſpleene,
To fight for, and maintaine.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Elſe might the world conuince of leuitie,
As well my vnder-takings as your counſels:
But I atteſt the gods, your full conſent
Gaue wings to my propenſion, and cut off
All feares attending on ſo dire a proie.
For what (alas) can theſe my ſingle armes?
What propugnation is in one mans valour
To ſtand the puſh and enmity of thoſe
This quarrell would excite? Yet I proteſt,
Were I alone to paſſe the difficulties,
And had as ample power, as I haue will,
Paris ſhould ne’re retra what he hath done,
Nor faint in the purſuite.

speech.speaker: Pri.
speech.line: Paris, you ſpeake
Like one be-ſotted on your ſweet delights;
You haue the Hony ſtill, but theſe the Gall,
So to be valiant, is no praiſe at all.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Sir, I propoſe not meerely to my ſelfe,
The pleaſures ſuch a beauty brings with it:
But I would haue the ſoyle of her faire Rape
Wip’d off in honourable keeping her.
What Treaſon were it to the ranſack’d Queene,
Diſgrace to your great worths, and ſhame to me,
Now to deliuer her poſſeſsion vp
On termes of baſe compulſion? Can it be,
That ſo degenerate a ſtraine as this,
Should once ſet footing in your generous boſomes?
There’s not the meaneſt ſpirit on our partie,
Without a heart to dare, or ſword to draw,
When Helen is defended: nor none ſo Noble,
Whoſe life were ill beſtow’d, or death vnfam’d,
Where Helen is the ſubie. Then (I ſay)
Well may we fight for her, whom we know well,
The worlds large ſpaces cannot paralell.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Paris and Troylus, you haue both ſaid well:
And on the cauſe and queſtion now in hand,
Haue gloz’d, but ſuperficially; not much
Vnlike young men, whom Ariſtotle thought
Vnfit to heare Morall Philoſophie.
The Reaſons you alledge, do more conduce
To the hot paſſion of diſtemp’red blood,
Then to make vp a free determination
‘Twixt right and wrong: For pleaſure, and reuenge,
Haue eares more deafe then Adders, to the voyce
Of any true deciſion. Nature craues
All dues be rendred to their Owners: now
What neerer debt in all humanity,
Then Wife is to the Husband? If this law
Of Nature be corrupted through affeion,
And that great mindes of partiall indulgence,
To their benummed wills reſiſt the ſame,
There is a Law in each well-ordred Nation,
To curbe thoſe raging appetites that are
Moſt diſobedient and refraurie.
If Helen then be wife to Sparta’s King
(As it is knowne ſhe is) theſe Morall Lawes
Of Nature, and of Nation, ſpeake alowd
To haue her backe return’d. Thus to perſiſt
In doing wrong, extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heauie. Heors opinion
Is this in way of truth: yet nere the leſſe,
My ſpritely brethren, I propend to you
In reſolution to keepe Helen ſtill;
For ‘tis a cauſe that hath no meane dependance,
Vpon our ioynt and ſeuerall dignities.

speech.speaker: Tro.
speech.line: Why? there you toucht the life of our deſigne:
Were it not glory that we more affeed,
Then the performance of our heauing ſpleenes,
I would not wiſh a drop of Troian blood,
Spent more in her defence. But worthy Heor,
She is a theame of honour and renowne,
A ſpurre to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whoſe preſent courage may beate downe our foes,
And fame in time to come canonize vs.
For I preſume braue Heor would not looſe
So rich aduantage of a promiſ’d glory,
As ſmiles vpon the fore-head of this aion,
For the wide worlds reuenew.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I am yours,
You valiant off-ſpring of great Priamus,
I haue a roiſting challenge ſent among’ſt
The dull and faious nobles of the Greekes,
Will ſtrike amazement to their drowſie ſpirits,
I was aduertiz’d, their Great generall ſlept,
Whil’ſt emulation in the armie crept:
This I preſume will wake him.
How now Therſites? what loſt in the Labyrinth of thy
furie? ſhall the Elephant Aiax carry it thus? he beates
me, and I raile at him: O worthy ſatisfaion, would it
were otherwiſe: that I could beate him, whil’ſt he rail’d
at me: Sfoote, Ile learne to coniure and raiſe Diuels, but
Ile ſee ſome iſſue of my ſpitefull execrations. Then ther’s
Achilles, a rare Enginer. If Troy be not taken till theſe two
vndermine it, the wals will ſtand till they fall of them —
ſelues. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget
that thou art Ioue the King of gods: and Mercury, looſe
all the Serpentine craft of thy Caduceus, if thou take not
that little little leſſe then little wit from them that they
haue, which ſhort-arm’d ignorance it ſelfe knowes, is ſo
abundant ſcarſe, it will not in circumuention deliuer a
Flye from a Spider, without drawing the maſſie Irons and
cutting the web: after this, the vengeance on the whole
Camp, or rather the bone-ach, for that me thinkes is the
curſe dependant on thoſe that warre for a placket. I haue
ſaid my prayers and diuell, enuie, ſay Amen: What ho?
my Lord Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Who’s there? Therſites. Good Therſites come
in and raile.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: If I could haue remembred a guilt counterfeit,
thou would’ſt not haue ſlipt out of my contemplation,
but it is no matter, thy ſelfe vpon thy ſelfe. The common
curſe of mankinde, follie and ignorance be thine in great
reuenew; heauen bleſſe thee from a Tutor, and Diſcipline
come not neere thee. Let thy bloud be thy direion till
thy death, then if ſhe that laies thee out ſayes thou art a
faire coarſe, Ile be ſworne and ſworne vpon’t ſhe neuer
ſhrowded any but Lazars, Amen. Wher’s Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: What art thou deuout? waſt thou in a prayer?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I, the heauens heare me.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Therſites, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Where, where, art thou come? why my cheeſe,
my digeſtion, why haſt thou not ſeru’d thy ſelfe into my
Table, ſo many meales? Come, what’s Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thy Commander Achilles, then tell me Patro —
clus, what’s Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Thy Lord Therſites: then tell me I pray thee,
what’s thy ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Thy knower Patroclus: then tell me Patroclus,
what art thou?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Thou maiſt tell that know’ſt.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: O tell, tell.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Ile declin the whole queſtion: Agamemnon com —
mands Achilles, Achilles is my Lord, I am Patroclus know —
er, and Patroclus is a foole.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: You raſcall.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Peace foole, I haue not done.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: He is a priuiledg’d man, proceede Therſites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon is a foole, Achilles is a foole, Ther —
sites is a foole, and as aforeſaid, Patroclus is a foole.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Deriue this? come?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon is a foole to offer to command A —
chilles, Achilles is a foole to be commanded of Agamemon,
Therſites is a foole to ſerue ſuch a foole: and Patroclus is a
foole positiue.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Why am I a foole?

scene.stagedir: Enter Agamemnon, Vliſſes, Neſtor, Diomedes, Aiax, and Chalcas.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Make that demand to the Creator, it ſuffiſes me
thou art. Looke you, who comes here?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Patroclus, Ile ſpeake with no body: come in
with me Therſites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Here is ſuch patcherie, ſuch iugling, and ſuch
knauerie: all the argument is a Cuckold and a Whore, a
good quarrel to draw emulations, faions, and bleede to
death vpon: Now the dry Suppeago on the Subie, and
Warre and Lecherie confound all.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Where is Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Within his Tent, but ill diſpoſ’d my Lord.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Let it be knowne to him that we are here:
He ſent our Meſſengers, and we lay by
Our appertainments, viſiting of him:
Let him be told of, ſo perchance he thinke
We dare not moue the queſtion of our place,
Or know not what we are.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: I ſhall ſo ſay to him.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: We ſaw him at the opening of his Tent,
He is not ſicke.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Yes, Lyon ſicke, ſicke of proud heart; you may
call it Melancholly if will fauour the man, but by my
head, it is pride; but why, why, let him ſhow vs the cauſe?
A word my Lord.

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: What moues Aiax thus to bay at him?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Achilles hath inueigled his Foole from him.

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: Who, Therſites?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: He.

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: Then will Aiax lacke matter, if he haue loſt his
Argument.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: No, you ſee he is his argument that has his argu —
ment Achilles.

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: All the better, their fraion is more our wiſh
then their faion; but it was a ſtrong counſell that a
Foole could diſunite.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: The amitie that wiſedome knits, not folly may
eaſily vntie.
Here comes Patroclus.

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: No Achilles with him?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: The Elephant hath ioynts, but none for curteſie:
His legge are legs for neceſſitie, not for flight.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: Achilles bids me ſay he is much ſorry:
If any thing more then your ſport and pleaſure,
Did moue your greatneſſe, and this noble State,
To call vpon him; he hopes it is no other,
But for your health, and your digeſtion ſake;
An after Dinners breath.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Heare you Patroclus:
We are too well acquainted with theſe anſwers:
But his euaſion winged thus ſwift with ſcorne,
Cannot outflye our apprehenſions.
Much attribute he hath, and much the reaſon,
Why we aſcribe it to him, yet all his vertues,
Not vertuouſly of his owne part beheld,
Doe in our eyes, begin to looſe their gloſſe;
Yea, and like faire Fruit in an vnholdſome diſh,
Are like to rot vntaſted: goe and tell him,
We came to ſpeake with him; and you ſhall not ſinne,
If you doe ſay, we thinke him ouer proud,
And vnder honeſt; in ſelfe-aſſumption greater
Then in the note of iudgement: & worthier then himſelfe
Here tends the ſauage ſtrangeneſſe he puts on,
Diſguiſe the holy ſtrength of their command:
And vnder write in an obſeruing kinde
His humorous predominance, yea watch
His pettiſh lines, his ebs, his flowes, as if
The paſſage and whole carriage of this aion
Rode on his tyde. Goe tell him this, and adde,
That if he ouerhold his price ſo much,
Weele none of him; but let him, like an Engin
Not portable, lye vnder this report.
Bring aion hither, this cannot goe to warre:
A ſtirring Dwarfe, we doe allowance giue,
Before a ſleeping Gyant: tell him ſo.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: I ſhall, and bring his anſwer preſently.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: In ſecond voyce weele not be ſatisfied,
We come to ſpeake with him, Vliſſes enter you.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: What is he more then another?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: No more then what he thinkes he is.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Is he ſo much, doe you not thinke, he thinkes
himſelfe a better man then I am?

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: No queſtion.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Will you ſubſcribe his thought, and ſay he is?

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: No, Noble Aiax, you are as ſtrong, as valiant, as
wiſe, no leſſe noble, much more gentle, and altogether
more traable.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Why ſhould a man be proud? How doth pride
grow? I know not what it is.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Your minde is the cleerer Aiax, and your vertues
the fairer; he that is proud, eates vp himſelfe; Pride is his
owne Glaſſe, his owne trumpet, his owne Chronicle, and
what euer praiſes it ſelfe but in the deede, deuoures the
deede in the praiſe.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the ingendring
of Toades.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Yet he loues himſelfe: is’t not ſtrange?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Achilles will not to the field to morrow.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: What’s his excuſe?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: He doth relye on none,
But carries on the ſtreame of his diſpoſe,
Without obſeruance or respe of any,
In will peculiar, and in ſelfe admiſſion.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Why, will he not vpon our faire requeſt,
Vntent his perſon, and ſhare the ayre with vs?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Things ſmall as nothing, for requeſts ſake onely
He makes important; poſſeſt he is with greatneſſe,
And ſpeakes not to himſelfe, but with a pride
That quarrels at ſelfe-breath. Imagin’d wroth
Holds in his bloud ſuch ſwolne and hot diſcourſe,
That twixt his mentall and his aiue parts,
Kingdom’d Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters gainſt it ſelfe; what ſhould I ſay?
He is ſo plaguy proud, that the death tokens of it,
Cry no recouery.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: Let Aiax goe to him.
Deare Lord, goe you and greete him in his Tent;
‘Tis ſaid he holds you well, and will be led
At your requeſt a little from himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: O Agamemnon, let it not be ſo.
Weele conſecrate the ſteps that Aiax makes,
When they goe from Achilles; ſhall the proud Lord,
That baſtes his arrogance with his owne ſeame,
And neuer ſuffers matter of the world,
Enter his thoughts: ſaue ſuch as doe reuolue
And ruminate himſelfe. Shall he be worſhipt,
Of that we hold an Idoll, more then hee?
No, this thrice worthy and right valiant Lord,
Muſt not ſo ſtaule his Palme, nobly acquir’d,
Nor by my will aſſubiugate his merit,
As amply titled as Achilles is: by going to Achilles,
That were to enlard his fat already, pride,
And adde more Coles to Cancer, when he burnes
With entertaining great Hiperion.
This L. goe to him? Iupiter forbid,
And ſay in thunder, Achilles goe to him.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: O this is well, he rubs the veine of him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: And how his ſilence drinkes vp this applauſe.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: If I goe to him, with my armed fiſt, Ile paſh him
ore the face.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: O no, you ſhall not goe.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: And a be proud with me, ile pheſe his pride: let
me goe to him.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Not for the worth that hangs vpon our quarrel.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: A paultry inſolent fellow.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: How he deſcribes himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Can he not be ſociable?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: The Rauen chides blackneſſe.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Ile let his humours bloud.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: He will be the Phyſitian that ſhould be the pa —
tient.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: And all men were a my minde.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Wit would be out of faſhion.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: A ſhould not beare it ſo, a ſhould eate Swords
firſt: ſhall pride carry it?

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: And ‘twould, you’ld carry halfe.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: A would haue ten ſhares.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I will knede him, Ile make him ſupple, hee’s not
yet through warme.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Force him with praiſes, poure in, poure in: his am —
bition is dry.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: My L. you feede too much on this diſlike.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Our noble Generall, doe not doe ſo.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: You muſt prepare to fight without Achilles.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Why, ‘tis this naming of him doth him harme.
Here is a man, but ‘tis before his face,
I will be ſilent.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Wherefore ſhould you ſo?
He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: ‘Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: A horſon dog, that ſhal palter thus with vs, would
he were a Troian.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: What a vice were it in Aiax now— —

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: If he were proud.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Or couetous of praiſe.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: I, or ſurley borne.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Or ſtrange, or ſelfe affeed.

speech.speaker: Vl.
speech.line: Thank the heauens L. thou art of ſweet compoſure;
Praiſe him that got thee, ſhe that gaue thee ſucke:
Fame be thy Tutor, and thy parts of nature
Thrice fam’d beyond, beyond all erudition;
But he that diſciplin’d thy armes to fight,
Let Mars deuide Eternity in twaine,
And giue him halfe, and for thy vigour,
Bull-bearing Milo: his addition yeelde
To ſinnowie Aiax: I will not praiſe thy wiſdome,
Which like a bourne, a pale, a ſhore confines
Thy ſpacious and dilated parts; here’s Neſtor
Inſtrued by the Antiquary times:
He muſt, he is, he cannot but be wiſe.
But pardon Father Neſtor, were your dayes
As greene as Aiax, and your braine ſo temper’d,
You ſhould not haue the eminence of him,
But be as Aiax.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Shall I call you Father?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: I my good Sonne.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Be rul’d by him Lord Aiax.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: There is no tarrying here, the Hart Achilles
Keepes thicket: pleaſe it our Generall,
To call together all his ſtate of warre,
Freſh Kings are come to Troy; to morrow
We muſt with all our maine of power ſtand faſt:
And here’s a Lord, come Knights from Eaſt to Weſt,
And cull their flowre, Aiax ſhall cope the beſt.

speech.speaker: Ag.
speech.line: Goe we to Counſaile, let Achilles ſleepe;
Light Botes may ſaile ſwift, though greater bulkes draw
deepe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Friend, you, pray you a word: Doe not you fol —
low the yong Lord Paris?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I ſir, when he goes before me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You depend vpon him I meane?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir, I doe depend vpon the Lord.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You depend vpon a noble Gentleman: I muſt
needes praiſe him.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: The Lord be praiſed.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: You know me, doe you not?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Faith ſir, ſuperficially.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Friend know me better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I hope I ſhall know your honour better.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: I doe deſire it.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: You are in the ſtate of Grace?

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Grace, not ſo friend, honor and Lordſhip are my
title: What Muſique is this?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I doe but partly know ſir: it is Muſicke in parts.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Know you the Muſitians.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Wholly ſir.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Who play they to?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: To the hearers ſir.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: At whoſe pleaſure friend?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: At mine ſir, and theirs that loue Muſicke.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Command, I meane friend.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Who ſhall I command ſir?

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Friend, we vnderſtand not one another: I am too
courtly, and thou art too cunning. At whoſe requeſt doe
theſe men play?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: That’s too’t indeede ſir: marry ſir, at the requeſt
of Paris my L. who’s there in perſon; with him the mor —
tall Venus, the heart bloud of beauty, loues inuiſible
ſoule.

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: Who? my Coſin Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: No ſir, Helen, could you not finde out that by
her attributes?

speech.speaker: Pa.
speech.line: It ſhould ſeeme fellow, that thou haſt not ſeen the
Lady Creſſida. I come to ſpeake with Paris from the
Prince Troylus: I will make a complementall aſſault vpon
him, for my buſineſſe ſeethes.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sodden buſineſſe, there’s a ſtewed phraſe indeede.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Faire be to you my Lord, and to all this faire com —
pany: faire deſires in all faire meaſure fairely guide them,
eſpecially to you faire Queene, faire thoughts be your
faire pillow.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Deere L. you are full of faire words.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You ſpeake your faire pleaſure ſweete Queene:
faire Prince, here is good broken Muſicke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: You haue broke it cozen: and by my life you
ſhall make it whole againe, you ſhall peece it out with a
peece of your performance. Nel, he is full of harmony.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Truely Lady no.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: O ſir.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Rude in ſooth, in good ſooth very rude.

speech.speaker: Paris.
speech.line: Well ſaid my Lord: well, you ſay ſo in fits.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I haue buſineſſe to my Lord, deere Queene: my
Lord will you vouchſafe me a word.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Nay, this ſhall not hedge vs out, weele heare you
ſing certainely.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Well ſweete Queene you are pleaſant with me,
but, marry thus my Lord, my deere Lord, and moſt eſtee —
med friend your brother Troylus.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: My Lord Pandarus, hony ſweete Lord.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Go too ſweete Queene, goe to.
Commends himſelfe moſt affeionately to you.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: You ſhall not bob vs out of our melody:
If you doe, our melancholly vpon your head.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Sweete Queene, ſweete Queene, that’s a ſweete
Queene Ifaith— —

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: And to make a ſweet Lady ſad, is a ſower offence.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nay, that ſhall not ſerue your turne, that ſhall it
not in truth la. Nay, I care not for ſuch words, no, no.
And my Lord he deſires you, that if the King call for him
at Supper, you will make his excuſe.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: My Lord Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What ſaies my ſweete Queene, my very, very
ſweete Queene?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: What exploit’s in hand, where ſups he to night?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Nay but my Lord?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What ſaies my ſweete Queene? my cozen will
fall out with you.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: You muſt not know where he ſups.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: With my diſpoſer Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: No, no; no ſuch matter, you are wide, come your
diſpoſer is ſicke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Well, Ile make excuſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I good my Lord: why ſhould you ſay Creſsida?
no, your poore diſpoſer’s ſicke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I ſpie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: You ſpie, what doe you ſpie: come, giue me an
Inſtrument now ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Why this is kindely done?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: My Neece is horrible in loue with a thing you
haue ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: She ſhall haue it my Lord, if it be not my Lord
Paris.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Hee? no, ſheele none of him, they two are
twaine.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Falling in after falling out, may make them three.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Come, come, Ile heare no more of this, Ile ſing
you a ſong now.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: I, I, prethee now: by my troth ſweet Lord thou
haſt a fine fore-head.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I you may, you may.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Let thy ſong be loue: this loue will vndoe vs al.
Oh Cupid, Cupid, Cupid.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Loue? I that it ſhall yfaith.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I, good now loue, loue, nothing but loue.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: In good troth it begins ſo.
