stanza.line: Loue, loue, nothing but loue, ſtill more:
The Shaft confounds not that it wounds,
Theſe Louers cry, oh ho they dye;
Yet that which ſeemes the wound to kill,
Doth turne oh ho, to ha ha he:
Oh ho a while, but ha ha ha,
O he grones out for ha ha ha——hey ho.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: In loue yfaith to the very tip of the noſe.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: He eates nothing but doues loue, and that breeds
hot bloud, and hot bloud begets hot thoughts, and hot
thoughts beget hot deedes, and hot deedes is loue.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is this the generation of loue? Hot bloud, hot
thoughts, and hot deedes, why they are Vipers, is Loue a
generation of Vipers?
Sweete Lord, whoſe a field to day?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Heor, Deiphœbus, Helenus, Anthenor, and all the
gallantry of Troy. I would faine haue arm’d to day, but
my Nell would not haue it ſo.
How chance my brother Troylus went not?

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: He hangs the lippe at ſomething; you know all
Lord Pandarus?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Not I hony ſweete Queene: I long to heare how
they ſped to day:
Youle remember your brothers excuſe?

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: To a hayre.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Farewell ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: Commend me to your Neece.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I will ſweete Queene.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: They’re come from fielde: let vs to Priams Hall
To greete the Warriers. Sweet Hellen, I muſt woe you,
To helpe vnarme our Heor: his ſtubborne Buckles,
With theſe your white enchanting fingers toucht,
Shall more obey then to the edge of Steele,
Or force of Greekiſh ſinewes: you ſhall doe more
Then all the Iland Kings, diſarme great Heor.

speech.speaker: Hel.
speech.line: ‘Twill make vs proud to be his ſeruant Paris:
Yea what he ſhall receiue of vs in duetie,
Giues vs more palme in beautie then we haue:
Yea ouerſhines our ſelfe.
Sweete aboue thought I loue thee.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: How now, where’s thy Maiſter, at my Couzen
Creſsidas?

speech.speaker: Man.
speech.line: No ſir, he ſtayes for you to condu him thither.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: O here he comes: How now, how now?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Sirra walke off.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Haue you ſeene my Couſin?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: No Pandarus: I ſtalke about her doore
Like a ſtrange ſoule vpon the Stigian bankes
Staying for waftage. O be thou my Charon,
And giue me ſwift tranſportance to thoſe fields,
Where I may wallow in the Lilly beds
Propos’d for the deſeruer. O gentle Pandarus,
From Cupids ſhoulder plucke his painted wings,
And flye with me to Creſsid.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Walke here ith’ Orchard, Ile bring her ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I am giddy; expeation whirles me round,
Th’ imaginary reliſh is ſo ſweete,
That it inchants my ſence: what will it be
When that the watry pallats taſte indeede
Loues thrice reputed Near? Death I feare me
Sounding diſtruion, or ſome ioy too fine,
Too ſubtile, potent, and too ſharpe in ſweetneſſe,
For the capacitie of my ruder powers;
I feare it much, and I doe feare beſides,
That I ſhall looſe distinion in my ioyes,
As doth a battaile, when they charge on heapes
The enemy flying.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Shee’s making her ready, ſheele come ſtraight; you
muſt be witty now, ſhe does ſo bluſh, & fetches her winde
ſo ſhort, as if ſhe were fraid with a ſprite: Ile fetch her; it
is the prettieſt villaine, ſhe fetches her breath ſo ſhort as a
new tane Sparrow.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Euen ſuch a paſſion doth imbrace my boſome:
My heart beates thicker then a feauorous pulſe,
And all my powers doe their beſtowing looſe,
Like vaſſalage at vnawares encountring
The eye of Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Come, come, what neede you bluſh?
Shames a babie; here ſhe is now, ſweare the oathes now
to her, that you haue ſworne to me. What are you gone a —
gaine, you muſt be watcht ere you be made tame, muſt
you? come your wayes, come your wayes, and you draw
backward weele put you i’th fils: why doe you not ſpeak
to her? Come draw this curtaine, & let’s ſee your piure.
Alaſſe the day, how loath you are to offend day light? and
‘twere darke you’ld cloſe ſooner: So, ſo, rub on, and kiſſe
the miſtreſſe; how now, a kiſſe in fee-farme? build there
Carpenter, the ayre is ſweete. Nay, you ſhall fight your
hearts out ere I part you. The Faulcon, as the Tercell, for
all the Ducks ith Riuer: go too, go too.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You haue bereft me of all words Lady.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Words pay no debts; giue her deedes: but ſheele
bereaue you o’th’ deeds too, if ſhee call your aiuity in
queſtion: what billing againe? here’s in witneſſe where —
of the Parties interchangeably. Come in, come in, Ile go
get a fire?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Will you walke in my Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O Creſsida, how often haue I wiſht me thus?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Wiſht my Lord? the gods grant? O my Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What ſhould they grant? what makes this pret —
ty abruption: what too curious dreg eſpies my ſweete La —
dy in the fountaine of our loue?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: More dregs then water, if my teares haue eyes.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Feares make diuels of Cherubins, they neuer ſee
truely.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Blinde feare, that ſeeing reaſon leads, findes ſafe
footing, then blinde reaſon, ſtumbling without feare: to
feare the worſt, oft cures the worſe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Oh let my Lady apprehend no feare,
In all Cupids Pageant there is preſented no monſter.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Not nothing monſtrous neither?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nothing but our vndertakings, when we vowe
to weepe ſeas, liue in fire, eate rockes, tame Tygers; think —
ing it harder for our Miſtreſſe to deuiſe impoſition
inough, then for vs to vndergoe any difficultie impoſed.
This is the monſtruoſitie in loue Lady, that the will is in —
finite, and the execution confin’d; that the deſire is bound —
leſſe, and the a a ſlaue to limit.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: They ſay all Louers ſweare more performance
then they are able, and yet reſerue an ability that they
neuer performe: vowing more then the perfeion of ten;
and diſcharging leſſe then the tenth part of one. They
that haue the voyce of Lyons, and the a of Hares: are
they not Monſters?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Are there ſuch? ſuch are not we: Praiſe vs as we
are taſted, allow vs as we proue: our head ſhall goe bare
till merit crowne it: no perfeion in reuerſion ſhall haue
a praiſe in preſent: wee will not name deſert before his
birth, and being borne his addition ſhall be humble: few
words to faire faith. Troylus ſhall be ſuch to Creſſid, as
what enuie can ſay worſt, ſhall be a mocke for his truth;
and what truth can ſpeake trueſt, not truer then Troy-
lus.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Will you walke in my Lord?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What bluſhing ſtill? haue you not done talking
yet?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Wel! Vnckle, what folly I commit, I dedicate
to you.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I thanke you for that: if my Lord get a Boy of
you, youle giue him me: be true to my Lord, if he flinch,
chide me for it.

speech.speaker: Tro.
speech.line: You know now your hoſtages: your Vnckles word
and my firme faith.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Nay, Ile giue my word for her too: our kindred
though they be long ere they are wooed, they are con —
ſtant being wonne: they are Burres I can tell you, they’le
ſticke where they are throwne.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Boldneſſe comes to mee now, and brings mee
heart: Prince Troylus, I haue lou’d you night and day, for
many weary moneths.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Why was my Creſsid then ſo hard to win?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Hard to ſeeme won: but I was won my Lord
With the firſt glance; that euer pardon me,
If I confeſſe much you will play the tyrant:
I loue you now, but not till now ſo much
But I might maiſter it; infaith I lye:
My thoughts were like vnbrideled children grow
Too head-ſtrong for their mother: ſee we fooles,
Why haue I blab’d: who ſhall be true to vs
When we are ſo vnſecret to our ſelues?
But though I lou’d you well, I woed you not,
And yet good faith I wiſht my ſelfe a man;
Or that we women had mens priuiledge
Of ſpeaking firſt. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I ſhall ſurely ſpeake
The thing I ſhall repent: ſee, ſee, your ſilence
Comming in dumbneſſe, from my weakneſſe drawes
My ſoule of counſell from me. Stop my mouth.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: And ſhall, albeit ſweete Muſicke iſſues thence.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Pretty yfaith.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: My Lord, I doe beſeech you pardon me,
‘Twas not my purpoſe thus to beg a kiſſe:
I am aſham’d; O Heauens, what haue I done!
For this time will I take my leaue my Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Your leaue ſweete Creſſid?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Leaue: and you take leaue till to morrow mor —
ning.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Pray you content you.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What offends you Lady?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Sir, mine owne company.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You cannot ſhun your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Let me goe and try:
I haue a kinde of ſelfe recides with you:
But an vnkinde ſelfe, that it ſelfe will leaue,
To be anothers foole. Where is my wit?
I would be gone: I ſpeake I know not what.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Well know they what they ſpeake, that ſpeakes
ſo wiſely.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Perchance my Lord, I ſhew more craft then loue,
And fell ſo roundly to a large confeſſion,
To Angle for your thoughts: but you are wiſe,
Or elſe you loue not: for to be wiſe and loue,
Exceedes mans might, that dwels with gods aboue.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O that I thought it could be in a woman:
As if it can, I will preſume in you,
To feede for aye her lampe and flames of loue.
To keepe her conſtancie in plight and youth,
Out-liuing beauties outward, with a minde
That doth renew ſwifter then blood decaies:
Or that perſwaſion could but thus conuince me,
That my integritie and truth to you,
Might be affronted with the match and waight
Of ſuch a winnowed puritie in loue:
How were I then vp-lifted! but alas,
I am as true, as truths ſimplicitie,
And ſimpler then the infancie of truth.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: In that Ile warre with you.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O vertuous fight,
When right with right wars who ſhall be moſt right:
True ſwaines in loue, ſhall in the world to come
Approue their truths by Troylus, when their times,
Full of proteſt, of oath and big compare;
Wants ſimiles, truth tir’d with iteration,
As true as ſteele, as plantage to the Moone:
As Sunne to day: as Turtle to her mate:
As Iron to Adamant: as Earth to th’ Center:
Yet after all compariſons of truth,
(As truths authenticke author to be cited)
As true as Troylus, ſhall crowne vp the Verſe,
And ſanifie the numbers.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Prophet may you be:
If I be falſe, or ſwerue a haire from truth,
When time is old and hath forgot it ſelfe:
When water drops haue worne the Stones of Troy;
And blinde obliuion ſwallow’d Cities vp;
And mightie States charaerleſſe are grated
To duſtie nothing; yet let memory,
From falſe to falſe, among falſe Maids in loue,
Vpbraid my falſehood, when they’aue ſaid as falſe,
As Aire, as Water, as Winde, as ſandie earth;
As Foxe to Lambe; as Wolfe to Heifers Calfe;
Pard to the Hinde, or Stepdame to her Sonne;
Yea, let them ſay, to ſticke the heart of falſehood,
As falſe as Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Go too, a bargaine made: ſeale it, ſeale it, Ile
be the witneſſe here I hold your hand: here my Couſins,
if euer you proue falſe one to another, ſince I haue taken
ſuch paines to bring you together, let all pittifull goers
betweene be cal’d to the worlds end after my name: call
them all Panders; let all conſtant men be Troyluſſes, all
falſe women Creſſids, and all brokers betweene, Panders:
ſay, Amen.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Amen.
Whereupon I will ſhew you a Chamber, which bed, be —
cauſe it ſhall not ſpeake of your prettie encounters, preſſe
it to death: away.
And Cupid grant all tong-tide Maidens heere,
Bed, Chamber, and Pander, to prouide this geere.

scene.stagedir: Enter Vlyſſes, Diomedes, Neſtor, Agamemnon, Menelaus and Chalcas. Floriſh.

speech.speaker: Cal.
speech.line: Now Princes for the ſeruice I haue done you,
Th’ aduantage of the time promps me aloud,
To call for recompence: appeare it to your minde,
That through the ſight I beare in things to loue,
I haue abandon’d Troy, left my poſſeſſion,
Incur’d a Traitors name, expoſ’d my ſelfe,
From certaine and poſſeſt conueniences,
To doubtfull fortunes, ſequeſtring from me all
That time, acquaintance, cuſtome and condition,
Made tame, and moſt familiar to my nature:
And here to doe you ſeruice am become,
As new into the world, ſtrange, vnacquainted.
I doe beſeech you, as in way of taſte,
To giue me now a little benefit:
Out of thoſe many regiſtred in promiſe,
Which you ſay, liue to come in my behalfe.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: What would’ſt thou of vs Troian? make
demand?

speech.speaker: Cal.
speech.line: You haue a Troian prisoner, cal’d Anthenor,
Yeſterday tooke: Troy holds him very deere.
Oft haue you (often haue you, thankes therefore)
Deſir’d my Creſſid in right great exchange.
Whom Troy hath ſtill deni’d: but this Anthenor,
I know is ſuch a wreſt in their affaires;
That their negotiations all must ſlacke,
Wanting his mannage: and they will almoſt,
Giue vs a Prince of blood, a Sonne of Priam,
In change of him. Let him be ſent great Princes,
And he ſhall buy my Daughter: and her preſence,
Shall quite ſtrike off all ſeruice I haue done,
In moſt accepted paine.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Let Diomedes beare him,
And bring vs Creſſid hither: Calcas ſhall haue
What he requeſts of vs: good Diomed
Furniſh you fairely for this enterchange;
Withall bring word, if Heor will to morrow
Be anſwer’d in his challenge. Aiax is ready.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: This ſhall I vndertake, and ‘tis a burthen
Which I am proud to beare.

scene.stagedir: Enter Achilles and Patroclus in their Tent.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Achilles ſtands i’th entrance of his Tent;
Pleaſe it our Generall to paſſe ſtrangely by him,
As if he were forgot: and Princes all,
Lay negligent and looſe regard vpon him;
I will come laſt, ‘tis like heele queſtion me,
Why ſuch vnplauſiue eyes are bent? why turn’d on him?
If ſo, I haue deriſion medicinable,
To vſe betweene your ſtrangeneſſe and his pride,
Which his owne will ſhall haue deſire to drinke;
It may doe good, pride hath no other glaſſe
To ſhow it ſelfe, but pride: for ſupple knees,
Feede arrogance, and are the proud mans fees.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: Weele execute your purpoſe, and put on
A forme of ſtrangeneſſe as we paſſe along,
So doe each Lord, and either greete him not,
Or elſe diſdainfully, which ſhall ſhake him more,
Then if not lookt on. I will lead the way.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What comes the Generall to ſpeake with me?
You know my minde, Ile fight no more ‘gainſt Troy.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What ſaies Achilles, would he ought with vs?

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: Would you my Lord ought with the Generall?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Neſ.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: The better.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Good day, good day.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: How doe you? how doe you?

speech.speaker: Achi.
speech.line: What, do’s the Cuckold ſcorne me?

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: How now Patroclus?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Good morrow Aiax?

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Ha.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Good morrow.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: I, and good next day too.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What meane theſe fellowes? know they not
Achilles?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: They paſſe by ſtrangely: they were vſ’d to bend
To ſend their ſmiles before them to Achilles:
To come as humbly as they vs’d to creepe to holy Altars.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What am I poore of late?
‘Tis certaine, greatneſſe once falne out with fortune,
Muſt fall out with men too: what the declin’d is,
He ſhall as ſoone reade in the eyes of others,
As feele in his owne fall: for men like butter-flies,
Shew not their mealie wings, but to the Summer:
And not a man for being ſimply man,
Hath any honour; but honour’d for thoſe honours
That are without him; as place, riches, and fauour,
Prizes of accident, as oft as merit:
Which when they fall, as being ſlippery ſtanders;
The loue that leand on them as ſlippery too,
Doth one plucke downe another, and together
Dye in the fall. But ‘tis not ſo with me;
Fortune and I are friends, I doe enioy
At ample point, all that I did poſſeſſe,
Saue theſe mens lookes: who do me thinkes finde out
Something not worth in me ſuch rich beholding,
As they haue often giuen. Here is Vliſſes,
Ile interrupt his reading: how now Vliſſes?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Now great Thetis Sonne.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What are you reading?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: A ſtrange fellow here
Writes me, that man, how dearely euer parted,
How much in hauing, or without, or in,
Cannot make boaſt to haue that which he hath;
Nor feeles not what he owes, but by refleion:
As when his vertues ſhining vpon others,
Heate them, and they retort that heate againe
To the firſt giuer.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: This is not ſtrange Vliſſes:
The beautie that is borne here in the face,
The bearer knowes not, but commends it ſelfe,
Not going from it ſelfe: but eye to eye oppos’d,
Salutes each other with each others forme.
For ſpeculation turnes not to it ſelfe,
Till it hath trauail’d, and is married there
Where it may ſee it ſelfe: this is not ſtrange at all.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: I doe not ſtraine it at the poſition,
It is familiar; but at the Authors drift,
Who in his circumſtance, expreſly proues
That no may is the Lord of any thing,
(Though in and of him there is much conſiſting,)
Till he communicate his parts to others:
Nor doth he of himſelfe know them for ought,
Till he behold them formed in th’ applauſe,
Where they are extended: who like an arch reuerb’rate
The voyce againe; or like a gate of ſteele,
Fronting the Sunne, receiues and renders backe
His figure, and his heate. I was much rapt in this,
And apprehended here immediately:
The vnknowne Aiax;
Heauens what a man is there? a very Horſe,
That has he knowes not what. Nature, what things there are.
Moſt abie in regard, and deare in vſe.
What things againe moſt deere in the eſteeme,
And poore in worth: now ſhall we ſee to morrow,
An a that very chance doth throw vpon him?
Aiax renown’d? O heauens, what ſome men doe,
While ſome men leaue to doe!
How ſome men creepe in skittiſh fortunes hall,
Whiles others play the Ideots in her eyes:
How one man eates into anothers pride,
While pride is feaſting in his wantonneſſe
To ſee theſe Grecian Lords; why, euen already,
They clap the lubber Aiax on the ſhoulder,
As if his foote were on braue Heors breſt,
And great Troy ſhrinking.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I doe beleeue it:
For they paſt by me, as myſers doe by beggars,
Neither gaue to me good word, nor looke:
What are my deedes forgot?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Time hath (my Lord) a wallet at his backe,
Wherein he puts almes for obliuion:
A great ſiz’d monſter of ingratitudes:
Thoſe ſcraps are good deedes paſt,
Which are deuour’d as faſt as they are made,
Forgot as ſoone as done: perſeuerance, deere my Lord,
Keepes honor bright, to haue done, is to hang
Quite out of faſhion, like a ruſtie male,
In monumentall mockrie: take the inſtant way,
For honour trauels in a ſtraight ſo narrow,
Where one but goes a breaſt, keepe then the paths
For emulation hath a thouſand Sonnes,
That one by one purſue; if you giue way,
Or hedge aſide from the dire forth right;
Like to an entred Tyde, they all ruſh by,
And leaue you hindmoſt:
Or like gallant Horſe falne in firſt ranke,
Lye there for pauement to the abie, neere
Ore-run and trampled on: then what they doe in preſent,
Though leſſe then yours in paſt, must ore-top yours:
For time is like a faſhionable Hoſte,
That ſlightly ſhakes his parting Gueſt by th’ hand;
And with his armes out-ſtretcht, as he would flye,
Graſpes in the commer: the welcome euer ſmiles,
And farewels goes out ſighing: O let not vertue ſeeke
Remuneration for the thing it was: for beautie, wit,
High birth, vigor of bone, deſert in ſeruice,
Loue, friendſhip, charity, are ſubies all
To enuious and calumniating time:
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin:
That all with one conſent praiſe new borne gaudes,
Though they are made and moulded of things paſt,
And goe to duſt, that is a little guilt,
More laud then guilt oreduſted.
The preſent eye praiſes the preſent obie:
Then maruell not thou great and compleat man,
That all the Greekes begin to worſhip Aiax;
Since things in motion begin to catch the eye,
Then what not ſtirs: the cry went out on thee,
And ſtill it might, and yet it may againe,
If thou would’ſt not entombe thy ſelfe aliue,
And caſe thy reputation in thy Tent;
Whoſe glorious deedes, but in theſe fields of late,
Made emulous miſſions ‘mongſt the gods themſelues,
And draue great Mars to faion.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Of this my priuacie,
I haue ſtrong reaſons.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: But ‘gainſt your priuacie
The reaſons are more potent and heroycall:
‘Tis knowne Achilles, that you are in loue
With one of Priams daughters.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Ha? knowne?

speech.speaker: Vlis.
speech.line: Is that a wonder?
The prouidence that’s in a watchfull State,
Knowes almoſt euery graine of Plutoes gold;
Findes bottome in th’ vncomprehenſiue deepes;
Keepes place with thought; and almoſt like the gods,
Doe thoughts vnuaile in their dumbe cradles:
There is a myſterie (with whom relation
Durſt neuer meddle) in the ſoule of State;
Which hath an operation more diuine,
Then breath or pen can giue expreſſure to:
All the commerſe that you haue had with Troy,
As perfely is ours, as yours, my Lord.
And better would it fit Achilles much,
To throw downe Heor then Polixena.
But it muſt grieue yong Pirhus now at home,
When fame ſhall in her Iland ſound her trumpe;
And all the Greekiſh Girles ſhall tripping ſing,
Great Heors ſiſter did Achilles winne;
But our great Aiax brauely beate downe him.
Farewell my Lord: I as your louer ſpeake;
The foole ſlides ore the Ice that you ſhould breake.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: To this effe Achilles haue I mou’d you;
A woman impudent and manniſh growne,
Is not more loth’d, then an effeminate man,
In time of aion: I ſtand condemn’d for this;
They thinke my little ſtomacke to the warre,
And your great loue to me, reſtraines you thus:
Sweete, rouſe your ſelfe; and the weake wanton Cupid
Shall from your necke vnlooſe his amorous fould,
And like a dew drop from the Lyons mane,
Be ſhooke to ayrie ayre.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Shall Aiax fight with Heor?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: I, and perhaps receiue much honor by him.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I ſee my reputation is at ſtake,
My fame is ſhrowdly gored.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: O then beware:
Thoſe wounds heale ill, that men doe giue themſelues:
Omiſſion to doe what is neceſſary,
Seales a commiſſion to a blanke of danger,
And danger like an ague ſubtly taints
Euen then when we ſit idely in the ſunne.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Goe call Therſites hither ſweet Patroclus,
Ile ſend the foole to Aiax, and deſire him
T’ inuite the Troian Lords after the Combat
To ſee vs here vnarm’d: I haue a womans longing,
An appetite that I am ſicke withall,
To ſee great Heor in his weedes of peace;
To talke with him, and to behold his viſage,
Euen to my full of view. A labour ſau’d.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: A wonder.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Aiax goes vp and downe the field, asking for
himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: How ſo?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hee muſt fight ſingly to morrow with Heor,
and is ſo prophetically proud of an heroicall cudgelling,
that he raues in ſaying nothing.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: How can that be?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why he ſtalkes vp and downe like a Peacock, a
ſtride and a ſtand: ruminates like an hoſteſſe, that hath no
Arithmatique but her braine to ſet downe her recko —
ning: bites his lip with a politique regard, as who ſhould
ſay, there were wit in his head and twoo’d out; and ſo
there is: but it lyes as coldly in him, as fire in a flint,
which will not ſhew without knocking. The mans vn —
done for euer; for if Heor breake not his necke i’th’ com —
bat, heele break’t himſelfe in vaine-glory. He knowes
not mee: I ſaid, good morrow Aiax; And he replyes,
thankes Agamemnon. What thinke you of this man,
that takes me for the Generall? Hee’s growne a very
land-fiſh, languageleſſe, a monſter: a plague of o —
pinion, a man may weare it on both ſides like a leather
Ierkin.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Thou muſt be my Ambaſſador to him Therſites.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Who, I: why, heele anſwer no body: he pro —
feſſes not anſwering; ſpeaking is for beggers: he weares
his tongue in’s armes: I will put on his preſence; let Pa —
troclus make his demands to me, you ſhall ſee the Page —
ant of Aiax.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: To him Patroclus; tell him, I humbly deſire the
valiant Aiax, to inuite the moſt valorous Heor, to come
vnarm’d to my Tent, and to procure ſafe condu for his
perſon, of the magnanimious and moſt illuſtrious, ſixe or
ſeauen times honour’d Captaine, Generall of the Grecian
Armie Agamemnon, &c. doe this.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: Ioue bleſſe great Aiax.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hum.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: I come from the worthy Achilles.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Who moſt humbly deſires you to inuite Heor
to his Tent.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hum.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: And to procure ſafe condu from Agamemnon.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Agamemnon?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Ha?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: What ſay you too’t.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: God buy you with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Your anſwer ſir.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: If to morrow be a faire day, by eleuen a clocke
it will goe one way or other; howſoeuer, he ſhall pay for
me ere he has me.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Your anſwer ſir.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Fare you well with all my heart.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No, but he’s out a tune thus: what muſicke will
be in him when Heor has knockt out his braines, I know
not: but I am ſure none, vnleſſe the Fidler Apollo get his
ſinewes to make catlings on.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Come, thou ſhalt beare a Letter to him
ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Let me carry another to his Horſe; for that’s the
more capable creature.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: My minde is troubled like a Fountaine ſtir’d,
And I my ſelfe ſee not the bottome of it.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Would the Fountaine of your minde were cleere
againe, that I might water an Aſſe at it: I had rather be a
Ticke in a Sheepe, then ſuch a valiant ignorance.

scene.stagedir: Enter at one doore Æneas with a Torch, at another Paris, Diephœbus, Anthenor, Diomed the Grecian, with Torches.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: See hoa, who is that there?

speech.speaker: Dieph.
speech.line: It is the Lord Æneas.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Is the Prince there in perſon?
Had I ſo good occaſion to lye long
As you Prince Paris, nothing but heauenly buſineſſe,
Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: That’s my minde too: good morrow Lord
Æneas.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: A valiant Greeke Æneas, take his hand,
Witneſſe the proceſſe of your ſpeech within;
You told how Diomed, in a whole weeke by dayes
Did haunt you in the Field.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Health to you valiant ſir,
During all queſtion of the gentle truce:
But when I meete you arm’d, as blacke defiance,
As heart can thinke, or courage execute.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: The one and other Diomed embraces,
Our blouds are now in calme; and ſo long health:
But when contention, and occaſion meetes,
By Ioue, Ile play the hunter for thy life,
With all my force, purſuite and pollicy.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: And thou ſhalt hunt a Lyon that will flye
With his face backward, in humaine gentleneſſe:
Welcome to Troy; now by Anchiſes life,
Welcome indeede: by Venus hand I ſweare,
No man aliue can loue in ſuch a ſort,
The thing he meanes to kill, more excellently.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: We ſimpathize. Ioue let Æneas liue
(If to my ſword his fate be not the glory)
A thouſand compleate courſes of the Sunne,
But in mine emulous honor let him dye:
With euery ioynt a wound, and that to morrow.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: We know each other well.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: We doe, and long to know each other worſe.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: This is the moſt, deſpightful’ſt gentle greeting;
The nobleſt hatefull loue, that ere I heard of.
What buſineſſe Lord ſo early?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: I was ſent for to the King; but why, I know not.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: His purpoſe meets you; it was to bring this Greek
To Calcha’s houſe; and there to render him,
For the enfreed Anthenor, the faire Creſſid:
Lets haue your company; or if you pleaſe,
Haſte there before vs. I conſtantly doe thinke,
(Or rather call my thought a certaine knowledge)
My brother Troylus lodges there to night.
Rouſe him, and giue him note of our approach,
With the whole quality whereof, I feare
We ſhall be much vnwelcome.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: That I aſſure you:
Troylus had rather Troy were borne to Greece,
Then Creſſid borne from Troy.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: There is no helpe:
The bitter diſpoſition of the time will haue it ſo.
On Lord, weele follow you.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Good morrow all.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: And tell me noble Diomed: faith tell me true,
Euen in the ſoule of ſound good fellowſhip,
Who in your thoughts merits faire Helen moſt?
My ſelfe, or Menelaus?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Both alike.
He merits well to haue her, that doth ſeeke her,
Not making any ſcruple of her ſoylure,
With ſuch a hell of paine, and world of charge.
And you as well to keepe her, that defend her,
Not pallating the taſte of her diſhonour,
With ſuch a coſtly loſſe of wealth and friends:
He like a puling Cuckold, would drinke vp
The lees and dregs of a flat tamed peece:
You like a letcher, out of whoriſh loynes,
Are pleaſ’d to breede out your inheritors:
Both merits poyz’d, each weighs no leſſe nor more,
But he as he, which heauier for a whore.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: You are too bitter to your country-woman.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Shee’s bitter to her countrey: heare me Paris,
For euery falſe drop in her baudy veines,
A Grecians life hath ſunke: for euery ſcruple
Of her contaminated carrion weight,
A Troian hath beene ſlaine. Since ſhe could ſpeake,
She hath not giuen ſo many good words breath,
As for her, Greekes and Troians ſuffred death.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Faire Diomed, you doe as chapmen doe,
Diſpraiſe the thing that you deſire to buy:
But we in ſilence hold this vertue well;
Weele not commend, what we intend to ſell.
Here lyes our way.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Deere trouble not your ſelfe: the morne is cold.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Then ſweet my Lord, Ile call mine Vnckle down;
He ſhall vnbolt the Gates.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Trouble him not:
To bed, to bed: ſleepe kill thoſe pritty eyes,
And giue as ſoft attachment to thy ſences,
As Infants empty of all thought.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Good morrow then.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I prithee now to bed.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Are you a weary of me?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O Creſſida! but that the buſie day
Wak’t by the Larke, hath rouz’d the ribauld Crowes,
And dreaming night will hide our eyes no longer:
I would not from thee.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Night hath beene too briefe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Beſhrew the witch! with venemous wights ſhe ſtayes,
As hidiouſly as hell; but flies the graſpes of loue,
With wings more momentary, ſwift then thought:
You will catch cold, and curſe me.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Prithee tarry, you men will neuer tarry;
O fooliſh Creſſid, I might haue ſtill held off,
And then you would haue tarried. Harke, ther’s one vp?

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: What’s all the doores open here?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: It is your Vnckle.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: A peſtilence on him: now will he be mocking:
I ſhall haue ſuch a life.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: How now, how now? how goe maiden-heads?
Heare you Maide: wher’s my cozin Creſſid?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Go hang your ſelf, you naughty mocking Vnckle:
You bring me to doo——and then you floute me too.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: To do what? to do what? let her ſay what:
What haue I brought you to doe?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Come, come, beſhrew your heart: youle nere be
good, nor ſuffer others.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Ha, ha: alas poore wretch: a poore Chipochia, haſt
not ſlept to night? would he not (a naughty man) let it
ſleepe: a bug-beare take him.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Did not I tell you? would he were knockt ith’
head. Who’s that at doore? good Vnckle goe and ſee.
My Lord, come you againe into my Chamber:
You ſmile and mocke me, as if I meant naughtily.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Cre.
speech.line: Come you are deceiu’d, I thinke of no ſuch thing.
How earneſtly they knocke: pray you come in.
I would not for halfe Troy haue you ſeene here.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Who’s there? what’s the matter? will you beate
downe the doore? How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Good morrow Lord, good morrow.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Who’s there my Lord Æneas? by my troth I
knew you not: what newes with you ſo early?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Is not Prince Troylus here?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Here? what ſhould he doe here?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Come he is here, my Lord, doe not deny him:
It doth import him much to ſpeake with me.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is he here ſay you? ‘tis more then I know, Ile be
ſworne: For my owne part I came in late: what ſhould
he doe here?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Who, nay then: Come, come, youle doe him
wrong, ere y’are ware: youle be ſo true to him, to be
falſe to him: Doe not you know of him, but yet goe fetch
him hither, goe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: How now, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: My Lord, I ſcarce haue leiſure to ſalute you,
My matter is ſo raſh: there is at hand,
Paris your brother, and Deiphœbus,
The Grecian Diomed, and our Anthenor
Deliuer’d to vs, and for him forth-with,
Ere the firſt ſacrifice, within this houre,
We muſt giue vp to Diomeds hand
The Lady Creſſida.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Is it concluded ſo?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: By Priam, and the generall ſtate of Troy,
They are at hand, and ready to effe it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: How my atchieuements mocke me;
I will goe meete them: and my Lord Æneas,
We met by chance; you did not finde me here.

speech.speaker: Æn.
speech.line: Good, good, my Lord, the ſecrets of nature
Haue not more gift in taciturnitie.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible? no ſooner got but loſt: the diuell
take Anthenor; the yong Prince will goe mad: a plague
vpon Anthenor; I would they had brok’s necke.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: How now? what’s the matter? who was here?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Ah, ha!

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Why ſigh you ſo profoundly? wher’s my Lord?
gone? tell me ſweet Vnckle, what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Would I were as deepe vnder the earth as I am
aboue.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O the gods! what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Prythee get thee in: would thou had’ſt nere been
borne; I knew thou would’ſt be his death. O poore Gen —
tleman: a plague vpon Anthenor.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Good Vnckle I beſeech you, on my knees, I be —
ſeech you what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Thou muſt be gone wench, thou muſt be gone;
thou art chang’d for Anthenor: thou muſt to thy Father,
and be gone from Troylus: ‘twill be his death: ‘twill be
his baine, he cannot beare it.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O you immortall gods! I will not goe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Thou muſt.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I will not Vnckle: I haue forgot my Father:
I know no touch of conſanguinitie:
No kin, no loue, no bloud, no ſoule, ſo neere me,
As the ſweet Troylus: O you gods diuine!
Make Creſſids name the very crowne of falſhood!
If euer ſhe leaue Troylus: time, orce and death,
Do to this body what extremitie you can;
But the ſtrong baſe and building of my loue,
Is as the very Center of the earth,
Drawing all things to it. I will goe in and weepe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Doe, doe.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Teare my bright heire, and ſcratch my praiſed cheekes,
Cracke my cleere voyce with ſobs, and breake my heart
With ſounding Troylus. I will not goe from Troy.

scene.stagedir: Enter Paris, Troylus, Æneas, Deiphebus, Anthenor and Diomedes.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: It is great morning, and the houre prefixt
Of her deliuerie to this valiant Greeke
Comes faſt vpon: good my brother Troylus,
Tell you the Lady what ſhe is to doe,
And haſt her to the purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Walke into her houſe.
Ile bring her to the Grecian preſently;
And to his hand, when I deliuer her,
Thinke it an Altar, and thy brother Troylus
A Prieſt, there offring to it his heart.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: I know what ‘tis to loue,
And would, as I ſhall pittie, I could helpe.
Pleaſe you walke in, my Lords.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Be moderate, be moderate.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Why tell you me of moderation?
The griefe is fine, full perfe that I taſte,
And no leſſe in a ſenſe as ſtrong
As that which cauſeth it. How can I moderate it?
If I could temporiſe with my affeion,
Or brew it to a weake and colder pallat,
The like alaiment could I giue my griefe:
My loue admits no qualifying croſſe;
No more my griefe, in ſuch a precious loſſe.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Here, here, here, he comes, a ſweet ducke.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O Troylus, Troylus!

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: What a paire of ſpeacles is here? let me em —
brace too: oh hart, as the goodly ſaying is; O heart, hea —
uie heart, why ſigheſt thou without breaking? where he
anſwers againe; becauſe thou canſt not eaſe thy ſmart by
friendſhip, not by ſpeaking: there was neuer a truer rime;
let vs caſt away nothing, for we may liue to haue neede
of ſuch a Verſe: we ſee it, we ſee it: how now Lambs?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Creſſid: I loue thee in ſo ſtrange a puritie;
That the bleſt gods, as angry with my fancie,
More bright in zeale, then the deuotion which
Cold lips blow to their Deities: take thee from me.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Haue the gods enuie?

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: I, I, I, I, ‘tis too plaine a caſe.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: And is it true, that I muſt goe from Troy?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: A hatefull truth.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: What, and from Troylus too?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: From Troy, and Troylus.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Iſt poſſible?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: And ſodainely, where iniurie of chance
Puts backe leaue-taking, iuſtles roughly by
All time of pauſe; rudely beguiles our lips
Of all reioyndure: forcibly preuents
Our lockt embraſures; ſtrangles our deare vowes,
Euen in the birth of our owne laboring breath.
We two, that with ſo many thouſand ſighes
Did buy each other, muſt poorely ſell our ſelues,
With the rude breuitie and diſcharge of our
Iniurious time; now with a robbers haſte
Crams his rich theeuerie vp, he knowes not how.
As many farwels as be ſtars in heauen,
With diſtin breath, and conſign’d kiſſes to them,
He fumbles vp into a looſe adiew;
And ſcants vs with a ſingle famiſht kiſſe,
Diſtaſting with the ſalt of broken teares.

speech.speaker: Æneas
speech.line: My Lord, is the Lady ready?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Harke, you are call’d: ſome ſay the genius ſo
Cries, come to him that inſtantly muſt dye.
Bid them haue patience: ſhe ſhall come anon.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: Where are my teares? raine, to lay this winde,
Or my heart will be blowne vp by the root.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I muſt then to the Grecians?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: No remedy.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: A wofull Creſſid ‘mong’ſt the merry Greekes.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: When ſhall we ſee againe?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Here me my loue: be thou but true of heart.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I true? how now? what wicked deeme is this?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nay, we muſt vſe expoſtulation kindely,
For it is parting from vs:
I ſpeake not, be thou true, as fearing thee:
For I will throw my Gloue to death himſelfe,
That there’s no maculation in thy heart:
But be thou true, ſay I, to faſhion in
My ſequent proteſtation: be thou true,
And I will ſee thee.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O you ſhall be expoſ’d, my Lord to dangers
As infinite, as imminent: but Ile be true.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: And Ile grow friend with danger;
Weare this Sleeue.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: And you this Gloue.
When ſhall I ſee you?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I will corrupt the Grecian Centinels,
To giue thee nightly viſitation.
But yet be true.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O heauens: be true againe?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Heare why I ſpeake it; Loue:
The Grecian youths are full of qualitie,
Their louing well compos’d, with guift of nature,
Flawing and ſwelling ore with Arts and exerciſe:
How nouelties may moue, and parts with perſon.
Alas, a kinde of godly iealouſie;
Which I beſeech you call a vertuous ſinne:
Makes me affraid.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O heauens, you loue me not!

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Dye I a villaine then:
In this I doe not call your faith in queſtion
So mainely as my merit: I cannot ſing,
Nor heele the high Lauolt; nor ſweeten talke;
Nor play at ſubtill games; faire vertues all;
To which the Grecians are moſt prompt and pregnant:
But I can tell that in each grace of theſe,
There lurkes a ſtill and dumb-diſcourſiue diuell,
That tempts moſt cunningly: but be not tempted.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Doe you thinke I will:

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: No, but ſomething may be done that we wil not:
And ſometimes we are diuels to our ſelues,
When we will tempt the frailtie of our powers,
Preſuming on their changefull potencie.

speech.speaker: Æneas within.
speech.line: Nay, good my Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Come kiſſe, and let vs part.

speech.speaker: Paris
speech.line: Brother Troylus?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Good brother come you hither,
And bring Æneas and the Grecian with you.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: My Lord, will you be true?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Who I? alas it is my vice, my fault:
Whiles others fiſh with craft for great opinion,
I, with great truth, catch meere ſimplicitie;
Whil’ſt ſome with cunning guild their copper crownes,
With truth and plainneſſe I doe weare mine bare:
Feare not my truth; the morrall of my wit
Is plaine and true, ther’s all the reach of it.
Welcome ſir Diomed, here is the Lady
Which for Antenor, we deliuer you.
At the port (Lord) Ile giue her to thy hand,
And by the way poſſeſſe thee what ſhe is.
Entreate her faire; and by my ſoule, faire Greeke,
If ere thou ſtand at mercy of my Sword,
Name Creſſid, and thy life ſhall be as ſafe
As Priam is in Illion?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Faire Lady Creſsid,
So pleaſe you ſaue the thankes this Prince expes:
The luſtre in your eye, heauen in your cheeke,
Pleades your faire viſage, and to Diomed
You ſhall be miſtreſſe, and command him wholly.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Grecian, thou do’ſt not vſe me curteouſly,
To ſhame the ſeale of my petition towards,
I praiſing her. I tell thee Lord of Greece:
Shee is as farre high ſoaring o’re thy praiſes,
As thou vnworthy to be cal’d her ſeruant:
I charge thee vſe her well, euen for my charge:
For by the dreadfull Pluto, if thou do’ſt not,
(Though the great bulke Achilles be thy guard)
Ile cut thy throate.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Oh be not mou’d Prince Troylus;
Let me be priuiledg’d by my place and meſſage,
To be a ſpeaker free? when I am hence,
Ile anſwer to my luſt: and know my Lord;
Ile nothing doe on charge: to her owne worth
She ſhall be priz’d: but that you ſay, be’t ſo;
Ile ſpeake it in my ſpirit and honor, no.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Come to the Port. Ile tell thee Diomed,
This braue, ſhall oft make thee to hide thy head:
Lady, giue me your hand, and as we walke,
To our owne ſelues bend we our needefull talke.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: Harke, Heors Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: How haue we ſpent this morning
The Prince muſt thinke me tardy and remiſſe,
That ſwore to ride before him in the field.

speech.speaker: Par.
speech.line: ‘Tis Troylus fault: come, come, to field with him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Let vs make ready ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Yea, with a Bridegroomes freſh alacritie
Let vs addreſſe to tend on Heors heeles:
The glory of our Troy doth this day lye
On his faire worth, and ſingle Chiualrie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Aiax armed, Achilles, Patroclus, Agamemnon, Menelaus, Vliſſes, Neſtor, Calcas, &c.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Here art thou in appointment freſh and faire,
Anticipating time. With ſtarring courage,
Giue with thy Trumpet a loud note to Troy
Thou dreadfull Aiax, that the appauled aire
May pierce the head of the great Combatant,
And hale him hither.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Thou, Trumpet, ther’s my purſe;
Now cracke thy lungs, and ſplit thy braſen pipe:
Blow villaine, till thy ſphered Bias cheeke
Out-ſwell the collicke of puft Aquilon:
Come, ſtretch thy cheſt, and let thy eyes ſpout bloud:
Thou bloweſt for Heor.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: No Trumpet anſwers.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: ‘Tis but early dayes.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Is not yong Diomed with Calcas daughter?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: ‘Tis he, I ken the manner of his gate,
He riſes on the toe: that ſpirit of his
In aſpiration lifts him from the earth.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Is this the Lady Creſſid?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Euen ſhe.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Moſt deerely welcome to the Greekes, ſweete
Lady.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Our Generall doth ſalute you with a kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Yet is the kindeneſſe but particular; ‘twere bet —
ter ſhe were kiſt in generall.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: And very courtly counſell: Ile begin. So much
for Neſtor.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Ile take that winter from your lips faire Lady
Achilles bids you welcome.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: I had good argument for kiſſing once.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: But that’s no argument for kiſſing now;
For thus pop’t Paris in his hardiment.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Oh deadly gall, and theame of all our ſcornes,
For which we looſe our heads, to gild his hornes.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: The firſt was Menelaus kiſſe, this mine:
Patroclus kiſſes you.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Oh this is trim.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Paris and I kiſſe euermore for him.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ile haue my kiſſe ſir: Lady by your leaue.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: In kiſſing doe you render, or receiue.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Both take and giue.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Ile make my match to liue,
The kiſſe you take is better then you giue: therefore no
kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: Ile giue you boote, Ile giue you three for one.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: You are an odde man, giue euen, or giue none.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: An odde man Lady, euery man is odde.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: No, Paris is not; for you know ‘tis true,
That you are odde, and he is euen with you.

speech.speaker: Mene.
speech.line: You fillip me a’th’ head.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: No, Ile be ſworne.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: It were no match, your naile againſt his horne:
May I ſweete Lady beg a kiſſe of you?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: You may.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: I doe deſire it.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Why begge then?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Why then for Venus ſake, giue me a kiſſe:
When Hellen is a maide againe, and his— —

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I am your debtor, claime it when ‘tis due.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Neuer’s my day, and then a kiſſe of you.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Lady a word, Ile bring you to your Father.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: A woman of quicke ſence.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Fie, fie, vpon her:
Ther’s a language in her eye, her cheeke, her lip;
Nay, her foote ſpeakes, her wanton ſpirites looke out
At euery ioynt, and motiue of her body:
Oh theſe encounterers ſo glib of tongue,
That giue a coaſting welcome ere it comes;
And wide vnclaſpe the tables of their thoughts,
To euery tickling reader: ſet them downe,
For ſluttish ſpoyles of opportunitie:
And daughters of the game.

scene.stagedir: Enter all of Troy, Heor, Paris, Æneas, Helenus and Attendants. Floriſh.

speaker.short: ALL HECT., PAR., AENE., HEL., TRO.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: The Troians Trumpet.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Yonder comes the troope.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Haile all you ſtate of Greece: what ſhalbe done
To him that viory commands? or doe you purpoſe,
A vior ſhall be knowne: will you the Knights
Shall to the edge of all extremitie
Purſue each other; or ſhall be diuided
By any voyce, or order of the field: Heor bad aske?

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Which way would Heor haue it?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: He cares not, heele obey conditions.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: ‘Tis done like Heor, but ſecurely done,
A little proudly, and great deale diſpriſing
The Knight oppos’d.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: If not Achilles ſir, what is your name?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: If not Achilles, nothing.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Therefore Achilles: but what ere, know this,
In the extremity of great and little:
Valour and pride excell themſelues in Heor;
The one almoſt as infinite as all;
The other blanke as nothing: weigh him well:
And that which lookes like pride, is curteſie:
This Aiax is halfe made of Heors bloud;
In loue wherof, halfe Heor ſtaies at home:
Halfe heart, halfe hand, halfe Heor, comes to ſeeke
This blended Knight, halfe Troian, and halfe Greeke.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: A maiden battaile then? O I perceiue you.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Here is ſir, Diomed: goe gentle Knight,
Stand by our Aiax: as you and Lord Æneas
Conſent vpon the order of their fight,
So be it: either to the vttermoſt,
Or elſe a breach: the Combatants being kin,
Halfe ſtints their ſtrife, before their ſtrokes begin.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: They are oppos’d already.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: What Troian is that ſame that lookes ſo heauy?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: The yongeſt Sonne of Priam;
A true Knight; they call him Troylus;
Not yet mature, yet matchleſſe, firme of word,
Speaking in deedes, and deedeleſſe in his tongue;
Not ſoone prouok’t, nor being prouok’t, ſoone calm’d;
His heart and hand both open, and both free:
For what he has, he giues; what thinkes, he ſhewes;
Yet giues he not till iudgement guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impaire thought with breath:
Manly as Heor, but more dangerous;
For Heor in his blaze of wrath ſubſcribes
To tender obies; but he, in heate of aion,
Is more vindecatiue then iealous loue.
They call him Troylus; and on him ere,
A ſecond hope, as fairely built as Heor.
Thus ſaies Æneas, one that knowes the youth,
Euen to his inches: and with priuate ſoule,
Did in great Illion thus tranſlate him to me.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: They are in aion.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Now Aiax hold thine owne.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Heor, thou ſleep’ſt, awake thee.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: His blowes are wel diſpos’d there Aiax.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: You muſt no more.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Princes enough, ſo pleaſe you.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I am not warme yet, let vs fight againe.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: As Heor pleaſes.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Why then will I no more:
Thou art great Lord, my Fathers ſiſters Sonne;
A couſen german to great Priams ſeede:
The obligation of our bloud forbids
A gorie emulation ‘twixt vs twaine:
Were thy commixion, Greeke and Troian ſo,
That thou could’ſt ſay, this hand is Grecian all,
And this is Troian: the ſinewes of this Legge,
All Greeke, and this all Troy: my Mothers bloud
Runs on the dexter cheeke, and this ſiniſter
Bounds in my fathers: by Ioue multipotent,
Thou ſhould’ſt not beare from me a Greekiſh member
Wherein my ſword had not impreſſure made
Of our ranke feud: but the iuſt gods gainſay,
That any drop thou borrowd’ſt from thy mother,
My ſacred Aunt, ſhould by my mortall Sword
Be drained. Let me embrace thee Aiax:
By him that thunders, thou haſt luſtie Armes;
Heor would haue them fall vpon him thus.
Cozen, all honor to thee.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: I thanke thee Heor:
Thou art too gentle, and too free a man:
I came to kill thee Cozen, and beare hence
A great addition, earned in thy death.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Not Neoptolymus ſo mirable,
On whoſe bright creſt, fame with her lowd’ſt (O yes)
Cries, This is he; could’ſt promiſe to himſelfe,
A thought of added honor, torne from Heor.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: There is expeance here from both the ſides,
What further you will doe?

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Weele answere it:
The iſſue is embracement: Aiax, farewell.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: If I might in entreaties finde ſucceſſe,
As ſeld I haue the chance; I would deſire
My famous Couſin to our Grecian Tents.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: ‘Tis Agamemnons wiſh, and great Achilles
Doth long to ſee vnarm’d the valiant Heor.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Æneas, call my brother Troylus to me:
And ſignifie this louing enterview
To the expeers of our Troian part:
Deſire them home. Giue me thy hand, my Couſin:
I will goe eate with thee, and ſee your Knights.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Great Agamemnon comes to meete vs here.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: The worthieſt of them, tell me name by name:
But for Achilles, mine owne ſerching eyes
Shall finde him by his large and portly ſize.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Worthy of Armes: as welcome as to one
That would be rid of ſuch an enemie.
But that’s no welcome: vnderſtand more cleere
What’s paſt, and what’s to come, is ſtrew’d with huskes
And formeleſſe ruine of obliuion:
But in this extant moment, faith and troth,
Strain’d purely from all hollow bias drawing:
Bids thee with moſt diuine integritie,
From heart of very heart, great Heor welcome.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I thanke thee moſt imperious Agamemnon.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: My well-fam’d Lord of Troy, no leſſe to you.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Let me confirme my Princely brothers greeting,
You brace of warlike Brothers, welcome hither.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Who muſt we anſwer?

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: The Noble Menelaus.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: O, you my Lord, by Mars his gauntlet thanks,
Mocke not, that I affe th’ vntraded Oath,
Your quondam wife ſweares ſtill by Venus Gloue
Shee’s well, but bad me not commend her to you.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Name her not now ſir, ſhe’s a deadly Theame.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: O pardon, I offend.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: I haue (thou gallant Troyan) ſeene thee oft
Labouring for deſtiny, make cruell way
Through rankes of Greekiſh youth: and I haue ſeen thee
As hot as Perſeus, ſpurre thy Phrygian Steed,
And ſeene thee ſcorning forfeits and ſubduments,
When thou haſt hung thy aduanced ſword i’th’ ayre,
Not letting it decline, on the declined:
That I haue ſaid vnto my ſtanders by,
Loe Iupiter is yonder, dealing life.
And I haue ſeene thee pauſe, and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greekes haue hem’d thee in,
Like an Olympian wreſtling. This haue I ſeene,
But this thy countenance (ſtill lockt in ſteele)
I neuer ſaw till now. I knew thy Grandſire,
And once fought with him; he was a Souldier good,
But by great Mars, the Captaine of vs all,
Neuer like thee. Let an oldman embrace thee,
And (worthy Warriour) welcome to our Tents.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: ‘Tis the old Neſtor.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Let me embrace thee good old Chronicle,
That haſt ſo long walk’d hand in hand with time:
Moſt reuerend Neſtor, I am glad to claſpe thee.

speech.speaker: Ne.
speech.line: I would my armes could match thee in contention
As they contend with thee in courteſie.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I would they could.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Ha? by this white beard I’ld fight with thee to
morrow. Well, welcom, welcome: I haue ſeen the time.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: I wonder now, how yonder City ſtands,
When we haue heere her Baſe and pillar by vs.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I know your fauour Lord Vlyſſes well.
Ah ſir, there’s many a Greeke and Troyan dead,
Since firſt I ſaw your ſelfe, and Diomed
In Illion, on your Greekiſh Embaſſie.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Sir, I foretold you then what would enſue.
My propheſie is but halfe his iourney yet;
For yonder wals that pertly front your Towne,
Yond Towers, whoſe wanton tops do buſſe the clouds,
Must kiſſe their owne feet.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I muſt not beleeue you:
There they ſtand yet: and modeſtly I thinke,
The fall of euery Phrygian ſtone will coſt
A drop of Grecian blood: the end crownes all,
And that old common Arbitrator, Time,
Will one day end it.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: So to him we leaue it.
Moſt gentle, and moſt valiant Heor, welcome;
After the Generall, I beſeech you next
To Feaſt with me, and ſee me at my Tent.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I ſhall foreſtall thee Lord Vlyſſes, thou:
Now Heor I haue fed mine eyes on thee,
I haue with exa view perus’d thee Heor,
And quoted ioynt by ioynt.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Is this Achilles?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I am Achilles.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Stand faire I prythee, let me looke on thee.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Behold thy fill.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Nay, I haue done already.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Thou art to breefe, I will the ſecond time,
As I would buy thee, view thee, limbe by limbe.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: O like a Booke of ſport thou’lt reade me ore:
But there’s more in me then thou vnderſtand’ſt.
Why doeſt thou ſo oppreſſe me with thine eye?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Tell me you Heauens, in which part of his body
Shall I deſtroy him? Whether there, or there, or there,
That I may giue the locall wound a name,
And make diſtin the very breach, where-out
Heors great ſpirit flew. Anſwer me heauens.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: It would diſcredit the bleſt Gods, proud man,
To anſwer ſuch a queſtion: Stand againe;
Think’ſt thou to catch my life ſo pleaſantly,
As to prenominate in nice conieure
Where thou wilt hit me dead?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I tell thee yea.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Wert thou the Oracle to tell me ſo,
I’ld not beleeue thee: henceforth guard thee well,
For Ile not kill thee there, not there, nor there,
But by the forge that ſtythied Mars his helme,
Ile kill thee euery where, yea, ore and ore.
You wiſeſt Grecians, pardon me this bragge,
His inſolence drawes folly from my lips,
But Ile endeuour deeds to match theſe words,
Or may I neuer— —

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: Do not chafe thee Coſin:
And you Achilles, let theſe threats alone
Till accident, or purpoſe bring you too’t.
You may euery day enough of Heor
If you haue ſtomacke. The generall ſtate I feare,
Can ſcarſe intreat you to be odde with him.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I pray you let vs ſee you in the field,
We haue had pelting Warres ſince you refus’d
The Grecians cauſe.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Doſt thou intreat me Heor?
To morrow do I meete thee fell as death,
To night, all Friends.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Thy hand vpon that match.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Firſt, all you Peeres of Greece go to my Tent,
There in the full conuiue you: Afterwards,
As Heors leyſure, and your bounties ſhall
Concurre together, ſeuerally intreat him.
Beate lowd the Taborins, let the Trumpets blow,
That this great Souldier may his welcome know.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: My Lord Vlyſſes, tell me I beſeech you,
In what place of the Field doth Calchas keepe?

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: At Menelaus Tent, moſt Princely Troylus,
There Diomed doth feaſt with him to night,
Who neither lookes on heauen, nor on earth,
But giues all gaze and bent of amorous view
On the faire Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Shall I (ſweet Lord) be bound to thee ſo much,
After we part from Agamemnons Tent,
To bring me thither?

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: You ſhall command me ſir:
As gentle tell me, of what Honour was
This Creſſida in Troy, had ſhe no Louer there
That wailes her abſence?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O ſir, to ſuch as boaſting ſhew their ſcarres,
A mocke is due: will you walke on my Lord?
She was belou’d, ſhe lou’d; ſhe is, and dooth;
But ſtill ſweet Loue is food for Fortunes tooth.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Ile heat his blood with Greekiſh wine to night,
Which with my Cemitar Ile coole to morrow:
Patroclus, let vs Feaſt him to the hight.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Heere comes Therſites.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: How now, thou core of Enuy?
Thou cruſty batch of Nature, what’s the newes?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why thou piure of what thou ſeem’ſt, & Idoll
of Ideot-worſhippers, here’s a Letter for thee.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: From whence, Fragment?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why thou full diſh of Foole, from Troy.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Who keepes the Tent now?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: The Surgeons box, or the Patients wound.

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Well ſaid aduerſity, and what need theſe tricks?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Prythee be ſilent boy, I profit not by thy talke,
thou art thought to be Achilles male Varlot.

speech.speaker: Patro.
speech.line: Male Varlot you Rogue? What’s that?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Why his maſculine Whore. Now the rotten
diſeaſes of the South, guts-griping Ruptures, Catarres,
Loades a grauell i’th’ backe, Lethargies, cold Palſies, and
the like, take and take againe, ſuch prepoſtrous diſcoue —
ries.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Why thou damnable box of enuy thou, what
mean’ſt thou to curſe thus?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Do I curſe thee?

speech.speaker: Patr.
speech.line: Why no, you ruinous But, you whorſon indi —
ſtinguiſhable Curre.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No? why art thou then exaſperate, thou idle,
immateriall skiene of Sleyd ſilke; thou greene Sarcenet
flap for a ſore eye, thou taſſell of a Prodigals purſe thou:
Ah how the poore world is peſtred with ſuch water-flies,
diminutiues of Nature.

speech.speaker: Pat.
speech.line: Out gall.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Finch Egge.

speech.speaker: Ach.
speech.line: My ſweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite
From my great purpoſe in to morrowes battell:
Heere is a Letter from Queene Hecuba,
A token from her daughter, my faire Loue,
Both taxing me, and gaging me to keepe
An Oath that I haue ſworne. I will not breake it,
Fall Greekes, faile Fame, Honor or go, or ſtay,
My maior vow lyes heere; this Ile obay:
Come, come Therſites, helpe to trim my Tent,
This night in banquetting muſt all be ſpent.
Away Patroclus.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: With too much bloud, and too little Brain, theſe
two may run mad: but if with too much braine, and too
little blood, they do, Ile be a curer of madmen. Heere’s
Agamemnon, an honeſt fellow enough, and one that loues
Quailes, but he has not ſo much Braine as eare-wax; and
the goodly transformation of Iupiter there his Brother,
the Bull, the primatiue Statue, and oblique memoriall of
Cuckolds, a thrifty ſhooing-horne in a chaine, hanging
at his Brothers legge, to what forme but that he is, ſhold
wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit, turne
him too: to an Aſſe were nothing; hee is both Aſſe and
Oxe; to an Oxe were nothing, hee is both Oxe and Aſſe:
to be a Dogge, a Mule, a Cat, a Fitchew, a Toade, a Li —
zard, an Owle, a Puttocke, or a Herring without a Roe,
I would not care: but to be Menelaus, I would conſpire
againſt Deſtiny. Aske me not what I would be, if I were
not Therſites: for I care not to bee the lowſe of a Lazar,
ſo I were not Menelaus. Hoy-day, ſpirits and fires.

scene.stagedir: Enter Heor, Aiax, Agamemnon, Vlyſſes, Neſtor, Diomed, with Lights.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: We go wrong, we go wrong.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: No yonder ‘tis, there where we ſee the light.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I trouble you.

speech.speaker: Aiax.
speech.line: No, not a whit.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Heere comes himſelfe to guide you?

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Welcome braue Heor, welcome Princes all.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: So now faire Prince of Troy, I bid goodnight,
Aiax commands the guard to tend on you.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Thanks, and goodnight to the Greeks general.

speech.speaker: Men.
speech.line: Goodnight my Lord.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Goodnight ſweet Lord Menelaus.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Sweet draught: ſweet quoth-a? ſweet ſinke,
ſweet ſure.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Goodnight and welcom, both at once, to thoſe
that go, or tarry.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Goodnight.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Old Neſtor tarries, and you too Diomed,
Keepe Heor company an houre, or two.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I cannot Lord, I haue important buſineſſe,
The tide whereof is now, goodnight great Heor.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Giue me your hand.

speech.speaker: Vlyſ.
speech.line: Follow his Torch, he goes to Chalcas Tent,
Ile keepe you company.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Sweet ſir, you honour me.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: And ſo good night.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Come, come, enter my Tent.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: That ſame Diomed’s a falſe-hearted Rogue, a
moſt vniuſt Knaue; I will no more truſt him when hee
leeres, then I will a Serpent when he hiſſes: he will ſpend
his mouth & promiſe, like Brabler the Hound; but when
he performes, Aſtronomers foretell it, that it is prodigi —
ous, there will come ſome change: the Sunne borrowes
of the Moone when Diomed keepes his word. I will ra —
ther leaue to ſee Heor, then not to dogge him: they ſay,
he keepes a Troyan Drab, and vſes the Traitour Chalcas
his Tent. Ile after——Nothing but Letcherie? All
incontinent Varlets.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What are you vp here ho? ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Chal.
speech.line: Who cals?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Diomed, Chalcas (I thinke) wher’s your Daughter?

speech.speaker: Chal.
speech.line: She comes to you.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Stand where the Torch may not diſcouer vs.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Creſsid comes forth to him.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: How now my charge?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Now my ſweet gardian: harke a word with you.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Yea, ſo familiar?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: She will ſing any man at firſt ſight.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: And any man may finde her, if he can take her
life: ſhe’s noted.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Will you remember?

speech.speaker: Cal.
speech.line: Remember? yes.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Nay, but doe then; and let your minde be cou —
pled with your words.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What ſhould ſhe remember?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Liſt?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Sweete hony Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Roguery.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Nay then.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Ile tell you what.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Fo, fo, come tell a pin, you are a forſworne.— —

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: In faith I cannot: what would you haue me do?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: A iugling tricke, to be ſecretly open.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What did you ſweare you would beſtow on me?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I prethee do not hold me to mine oath,
Bid me doe not any thing but that ſweete Greeke.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Good night.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Hold, patience.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: How now Troian?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Diomed.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: No, no, good night: Ile be your foole no more.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Thy better muſt.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Harke one word in your eare.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O plague and madneſſe!

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: You are moued Prince, let vs depart I pray you,
Leſt your diſpleaſure ſhould enlarge it ſelfe
To wrathfull tearmes: this place is dangerous;
The time right deadly: I beſeech you goe.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Behold, I pray you.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Nay, good my Lord goe off:
You flow to great diſtraion: come my Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I pray thee ſtay?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: You haue not patience, come.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I pray you ſtay? by hell and hell torments,
I will not ſpeake a word.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: And ſo good night.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Nay, but you part in anger.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Doth that grieue thee? O withered truth!

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Why, how now Lord?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: By Ioue I will be patient.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Gardian? why Greeke?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Fo, fo, adew, you palter.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: In faith I doe not: come hither once againe.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: You ſhake my Lord at ſomething; will you goe?
you will breake out.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: She ſtroakes his cheeke.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Come, come.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nay ſtay, by Ioue I will not ſpeake a word.
There is betweene my will, and all offences,
A guard of patience; ſtay a little while.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: How the diuell Luxury with his fat rumpe and
potato finger, tickles theſe together: frye lechery, frye.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: But will you then?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: In faith I will lo; neuer truſt me elſe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Giue me ſome token for the ſurety of it.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Ile fetch you one.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: You haue ſworne patience.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Feare me not ſweete Lord.
I will not be my ſelfe, nor haue cognition
Of what I feele: I am all patience.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Now the pledge, now, now, now.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Here Diomed, keepe this Sleeue.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O beautie! where is thy Faith?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I will be patient, outwardly I will.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: You looke vpon that Sleeue? behold it well:
He lou’d me: O falſe wench: giue’t me againe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Whoſe was’t?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: It is no matter now I haue’t againe.
I will not meete with you to morrow night:
I prythee Diomed viſite me no more.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Now ſhe ſharpens: well ſaid Whetſtone.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I ſhall haue it.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: What, this?

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I that.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: O all you gods! O prettie, prettie pledge;
Thy Maiſter now lies thinking in his bed
Of thee and me, and ſighes, and takes my Gloue,
And giues memoriall daintie kiſſes to it;
As I kiſſe thee.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Nay, doe not ſnatch it from me.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: He that takes that, takes my heart withall.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I had your heart before, this followes it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I did ſweare patience.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: You ſhall not haue it Diomed; faith you ſhall not:
Ile giue you ſomething elſe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I will haue this: whoſe was it?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: It is no matter.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Come tell me whoſe it was?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: ‘Twas one that lou’d me better then you will.
But now you haue it, take it.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Whoſe was it?

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: By all Dianas waiting women yond:
And by her ſelfe, I will not tell you whoſe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: To morrow will I weare it on my Helme,
And grieue his ſpirit that dares not challenge it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Wert thou the diuell, and wor’ſt it on thy horne,
It ſhould be challeng’d.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Well, well, ‘tis done, ‘tis paſt; and yet it is not:
I will not keepe my word.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Why then farewell,
Thou neuer ſhalt mocke Diomed againe.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: You ſhall not goe: one cannot ſpeake a word,
But it ſtrait ſtarts you.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I doe not like this fooling.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Nor I by Pluto: but that that likes not me, plea —
ſes me beſt.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: What ſhall I come? the houre.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: I, come: O Ioue! doe, come: I ſhall be plagu’d.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Farewell till then.

speech.speaker: Creſ.
speech.line: Good night: I prythee come:
Troylus farewell; one eye yet lookes on thee;
But with my heart, the other eye, doth ſee.
Ah poore our ſexe; this fault in vs I finde:
The errour of our eye, dires our minde.
What errour leads, muſt erre: O then conclude,
Mindes ſwai’d by eyes, are full of turpitude.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: A proofe of ſtrength ſhe could not publiſh more;
Vnleſſe ſhe ſay, my minde is now turn’d whore.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Al’s done my Lord.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: It is.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Why ſtay we then?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: To make a recordation to my ſoule
Of euery ſyllable that here was ſpoke:
But if I tell how theſe two did coa;
Shall I not lye, in publiſhing a truth?
Sith yet there is a credence in my heart:
An eſperance ſo obſtinately ſtrong,
That doth inuert that teſt of eyes and eares;
As if thoſe organs had deceptious funions,
Created onely to calumniate.
Was Creſſed here?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: I cannot coniure Troian.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: She was not ſure.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Moſt ſure ſhe was.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Why my negation hath no taſte of madneſſe?

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Nor mine my Lord: Creſſid was here but now.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Let it not be beleeu’d for womanhood:
Thinke we had mothers; doe not giue aduantage
To ſtubborne Criticks, apt without a theame
For deprauation, to ſquare the generall ſex
By Creſſids rule. Rather thinke this not Creſſid.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: What hath ſhe done Prince, that can ſoyle our
mothers?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Nothing at all, vnleſſe that this were ſhe.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Will he ſwagger himſelfe out on’s owne eyes?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: This ſhe? no, this is Diomeds Creſſida:
If beautie haue a ſoule, this is not ſhe:
If ſoules guide vowes; if vowes are ſanimonie;
If ſanimonie be the gods delight:
If there be rule in vnitie it ſelfe,
This is not ſhe: O madneſſe of diſcourſe!
That cauſe ſets vp, with, and againſt thy ſelfe
By foule authoritie: where reaſon can reuolt
Without perdition, and loſſe aſſume all reaſon,
Without reuolt. This is, and is not Creſſid:
Within my ſoule, there doth conduce a ſight
Of this ſtrange nature, that a thing inſeperate,
Diuides more wider then the ſkie and earth:
And yet the ſpacious bredth of this diuiſion,
Admits no Orifex for a point as ſubtle,
As Ariachnes broken woofe to enter:
Inſtance, O inſtance! ſtrong as Plutoes gates:
Creſſid is mine, tied with the bonds of heauen;
Inſtance, O inſtance, ſtrong as heauen it ſelfe:
The bonds of heauen are ſlipt, diſſolu’d, and loos’d,
And with another knot fiue finger tied,
The fraions of her faith, orts of her loue:
The fragments, ſcraps, the bits, and greazie reliques,
Of her ore-eaten faith, are bound to Diomed

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
