speech.line: May worthy Troylus be halfe attached
With that which here his paſſion doth expreſſe?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: I Greeke: and that ſhall be divulged well
In Charaers, as red as Mars his heart
Inflam’d with Venus: neuer did yong man fancy
With ſo eternall, and ſo fixt a ſoule.
Harke Greek: as much I doe Creſſida loue;
So much by weight, hate I her Diomed,
That Sleeue is mine, that heele beare in his Helme:
Were it a Caske compos’d by Vulcans skill,
My Sword ſhould bite it: Not the dreadfull ſpout,
Which Shipmen doe the Hurricano call,
Conſtring’d in maſſe by the almighty Fenne,
Shall dizzie with more clamour Neptunes eare
In his diſcent; then ſhall my prompted ſword,
Falling on Diomed.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Heele tickle it for his concupie.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: O Creſſid! O falſe Creſſid! falſe, falſe, falſe:
Let all vntruths ſtand by thy ſtained name,
And theyle ſeeme glorious.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: O containe your ſelfe:
Your paſſion drawes eares hither.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: I haue beene ſeeking you this houre my Lord:
Heor by this is arming him in Troy.
Aiax your Guard, ſtaies to condu you home.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Haue with you Prince: my curteous Lord adew:
Farewell reuolted faire: and Diomed,
Stand faſt, and weare a Caſtle on thy head.

speech.speaker: Vli.
speech.line: Ile bring you to the Gates.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Accept diſtraed thankes.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Would I could meete that roague Diomed, I
would croke like a Rauen: I would bode, I would bode:
Patroclus will giue me any thing for the intelligence of
his whore: the Parrot will not doe more for an Almond,
then he for a commodious drab: Lechery, lechery, ſtill
warres and lechery, nothing elſe holds faſhion. A burning
diuell take them.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: When was my Lord ſo much vngently temper’d,
To ſtop his eares againſt admoniſhment?
Vnarme, vnarme, and doe not fight to day.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: You traine me to offend you: get you gone.
By the euerlaſting gods, Ile goe.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: My dreames will ſure proue ominous to the day.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: No more I ſay.

speech.speaker: Caſſa.
speech.line: Where is my brother Heor?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Here ſiſter, arm’d, and bloudy in intent:
Conſort with me in loud and deere petition:
Purſue we him on knees: for I haue dreampt
Of bloudy turbulence; and this whole night
Hath nothing beene but ſhapes, and formes of ſlaughter.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: O, ‘tis true.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Ho? bid my Trumpet ſound.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: No notes of ſallie, for the heauens, ſweet brother.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Begon I ſay: the gods haue heard me ſweare.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: The gods are deafe to hot and peeuiſh vowes;
They are polluted offrings, more abhord
Then ſpotted Liuers in the ſacrifice.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: O be perſwaded, doe not count it holy,
To hurt by being iuſt; it is as lawfull:
For we would count giue much to as violent thefts,
And rob in the behalfe of charitie.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: It is the purpoſe that makes ſtrong the vowe;
But vowes to euery purpoſe muſt not hold:
Vnarme ſweete Heor.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Hold you ſtill I ſay;
Mine honour keepes the weather of my fate:
Life euery man holds deere, but the deere man
Holds honor farre more precious, deere, then life.
How now yong man? mean’ſt thou to fight to day?

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Caſſandra, call my father to perſwade.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: No faith yong Troylus; doffe thy harneſſe youth:
I am to day ith’ vaine of Chiualrie:
Let grow thy Sinews till their knots be ſtrong;
And tempt not yet the bruſhes of the warre.
Vnarme thee, goe; and doubt thou not braue boy,
Ile ſtand to day, for thee, and me, and Troy.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Brother, you haue a vice of mercy in you;
Which better fits a Lyon, then a man.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: What vice is that? good Troylus chide me for it.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: When many times the captiue Grecian fals,
Euen in the fanne and winde of your faire Sword:
You bid them riſe, and liue.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: O ‘tis faire play.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Fooles play, by heauen Heor.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: How now? how now?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: For th’ loue of all the gods
Let’s leaue the Hermit Pitty with our Mothers,
And when we haue our Armors buckled on,
The venom’d vengeance ride vpon our ſwords,
Spur them to ruthfull worke, reine them from ruth.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Fie, ſauage, fie.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Heor, then ‘tis warres.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Troylus, I would not haue you fight to day.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Who ſhould with-hold me?
Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars,
Beckning with fierie trunchion my retire;
Not Priamus, and Hecuba on knees;
Their eyes ore-galled with recourſe of teares;
Nor you my brother, with your true ſword drawne
Oppoſ’d to hinder me, ſhould ſtop my way:
But by my ruine.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: Lay hold vpon him Priam, hold him faſt:
He is thy crutch; now if thou looſe thy ſtay,
Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee,
Fall all together.

speech.speaker: Priam.
speech.line: Come Heor, come, goe backe:
Thy wife hath dreampt: thy mother hath had viſions;
Caſſandra doth foreſee; and I my ſelfe,
Am like a Prophet ſuddenly enrapt,
to tell thee that this day is ominous:
Therefore come backe.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Æneas is a field,
And I do ſtand engag’d to many Greekes,
Euen in the faith of valour, to appeare
This morning to them.

speech.speaker: Priam.
speech.line: I, but thou ſhalt not goe,

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I muſt not breake my faith:
You know me dutifull, therefore deare ſir,
Let me not ſhame reſpe; but giue me leaue
To take that courſe by your conſent and voice,
Which you doe here forbid me, Royall Priam.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: O Priam, yeelde not to him.

speech.speaker: And.
speech.line: Doe not deere father.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Andromache I am offended with you:
Vpon the loue you beare me, get you in.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: This fooliſh, dreaming, ſuperſtitious girle,
Makes all theſe bodements.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: O farewell, deere Heor:
Looke how thou dieſt; looke how thy eye turnes pale:
Looke how thy wounds doth bleede at many vents:
Harke how Troy roares; how Hecuba cries out;
How poore Andromache ſhrils her dolour forth;
Behold diſtraion, frenzie, and amazement,
Like witleſſe Antickes one another meete,
And all cry Heor, Heors dead: O Heor!

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Away, away.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Farewell: yes, ſoft: Heor I take my leaue;
Thou do’ſt thy ſelfe, and all our Troy deceiue.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: You are amaz’d, my Liege, at her exclaime:
Goe in and cheere the Towne, weele forth and fight:
Doe deedes of praiſe, and tell you them at night.

speech.speaker: Priam.
speech.line: Farewell: the gods with ſafetie ſtand about
thee.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: They are at it, harke: proud Diomed, beleeue
I come to looſe my arme, or winne my ſleeue.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Doe you heare my Lord? do you heare?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: What now?

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Here’s a Letter come from yond poore girle.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Let me reade.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: A whorſon tiſicke, a whorſon raſcally tiſicke,
ſo troubles me; and the fooliſh fortune of this girle, and
what one thing, what another, that I ſhall leaue you one
o’th’s dayes: and I haue a rheume in mine eyes too; and
ſuch an ache in my bones; that vnleſſe a man were curſt,
I cannot tell what to thinke on’t. What ſayes ſhee
there?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Words, words, meere words, no matter from
the heart;
Th’ effe doth operate another way.
Goe winde to winde, there turne and change together:
My loue with words and errors ſtill ſhe feedes;
But edifies another with her deedes.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: Why, but heare you?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Hence brother lackie; ignomie and ſhame
Purſue thy life, and liue aye with thy name.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Now they are clapper-clawing one another, Ile
goe looke on: that diſſembling abhominable varlet Dio —
mede, has got that ſame ſcuruie, doting, fooliſh yong
knaues Sleeue of Troy, there in his Helme: I would faine
ſee them meet; that, that ſame yong Troian aſſe, that loues
the whore there, might ſend that Greekiſh whore-mai —
ſterly villaine, with the Sleeue, backe to the diſſembling
luxurious drabbe, of a ſleeueleſſe errant. O’th’ tother ſide,
the pollicie of thoſe craftie ſwearing raſcals; that ſtole
old Mouſe-eaten dry cheeſe, Neſtor: and that ſame dog —
foxe Vliſſes is not prou’d worth a Black-berry. They ſet
me vp in pollicy, that mungrill curre Aiax againſt that
dogge of as bad a kinde, Achilles. And now is the curre
Aiax prouder then the curre Achilles, and will not arme
to day. Whereupon, the Grecians began to proclaime
barbariſme; and pollicie growes into an ill opinion.
Soft, here comes Sleeue, and th’ other.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Flye not: for ſhould’ſt thou take the Riuer Stix,
I would ſwim after.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Thou do’ſt miſcall retire:
I doe not flye, but aduantagious care
Withdrew me from the oddes of multitude:
Haue at thee?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: Hold thy whore Grecian: now for thy whore
Troian: Now the Sleeue, now the Sleeue.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: What art thou Greek? art thou for Heors match?
Art thou of bloud, and honour?

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: No, no: I am a raſcall: a ſcuruie railing knaue:
a very filthy roague.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I doe beleeue thee, liue.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: God a mercy, that thou wilt beleeue me; but a
plague breake thy necke—for frighting me: what’s be —
come of the wenching rogues? I thinke they haue
ſwallowed one another. I would laugh at that mira —
cle— yet in a ſort, lecherie eates it ſelfe: Ile ſeeke them.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Goe, goe, my ſeruant, take thou Troylus Horſe;
Preſent the faire Steede to my Lady Creſſid:
Fellow, commend my ſeruice to her beauty;
Tell her, I haue chaſtiſ’d the amorous Troyan,
And am her Knight by proofe.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I goe my Lord.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Renew, renew, the fierce Polidamus
Hath beate downe Menon: baſtard Margarelon
Hath Doreus priſoner.
And ſtands Caloſſus-wiſe wauing his beame,
Vpon the paſhed courſes of the Kings:
Epiſtropus and Cedus, Polixines is ſlaine;
Amphimacus, and Thous deadly hurt;
Patroclus tane or ſlaine, and Palamedes
Sore hurt and bruiſed; the dreadfull Sagittary
Appauls our numbers, haſte we Diomed
To re-enforcement, or we periſh all.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Goe beare Patroclus body to Achilles,
And bid the ſnaile-pac’d Aiax arme for ſhame;
There is a thouſand Heors in the field:
Now here he fights on Galathe his Horſe,
And there lacks worke: anon he’s there a foote,
And there they flye or dye, like ſcaled ſculs,
Before the belching Whale; then is he yonder,
And there the ſtraying Greekes, ripe for his edge,
Fall downe before him, like the mowers ſwath;
Here, there, and euery where, he leaues and takes;
Dexteritie ſo obaying appetite,
That what he will, he does, and does ſo much,
That proofe is call’d impoſſibility.

speech.speaker: Vliſ.
speech.line: Oh, courage, courage Princes: great Achilles
Is arming, weeping, curſing, vowing vengeance;
Patroclus wounds haue rouz’d his drowzie bloud,
Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
That noſeleſſe, handleſſe, hackt and chipt, come to him;
Crying on Heor. Aiax hath loſt a friend,
And foames at mouth, and he is arm’d, and at it:
Roaring for Troylus; who hath done to day,
Mad and fantaſticke execution;
Engaging and redeeming of himſelfe.
With ſuch a careleſſe force, and forceleſſe care,
As if that luck in very ſpight of cunning, bad him win all.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Troylus, thou coward Troylus.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: I, there, there.

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: So, ſo, we draw together.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Where is this Heor?
Come, come, thou boy-queller, ſhew thy face:
Know what it is to meete Achilles angry.
Heor, wher’s Heor? I will none but Heor.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Troylus, thou coward Troylus, ſhew thy head.

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: Troylus, I ſay, wher’s Troylus?

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: What would’ſt thou?

speech.speaker: Diom.
speech.line: I would corre him.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Were I the Generall,
Thou ſhould’ſt haue my office,
Ere that correion: Troylus I ſay, what Troylus?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Oh traitour Diomed!
Turne thy falſe face thou traytor,
And pay thy life thou oweſt me for my horſe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: Ha, art thou there?

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: Ile fight with him alone, ſtand Diomed.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: He is my prize, I will not looke vpon.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Come both you coging Greekes, haue at you
both.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Yea Troylus? O well fought my yongeſt Brother.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Now doe I ſee thee; haue at thee Heor.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Pause if thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: I doe diſdaine thy curteſie, proud Troian;
Be happy that my armes are out of vſe:
My reſt and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon ſhalt heare of me againe:
Till when, goe ſeeke thy fortune.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Fare thee well:
I would haue beene much more a freſher man,
Had I expeed thee: how now my Brother?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Aiax hath tane Æneas; ſhall it be?
No, by the flame of yonder glorious heauen,
He ſhall not carry him: Ile be tane too,
Or bring him off: Fate heare me what I ſay;
I wreake not, though thou end my life to day.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Stand, ſtand, thou Greeke,
Thou art a goodly marke:
No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well,
Ile fruſh it, and vnlocke the riuets all,
But Ile be maiſter of it: wilt thou not beaſt abide?
Why then flye on, Ile hunt thee for thy hide.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Come here about me you my Myrmidons:
Marke what I ſay; attend me where I wheele:
Strike not a ſtroake, but keepe your ſelues in breath;
And when I haue the bloudy Heor found,
Empale him with your weapons round about:
In felleſt manner execute your arme.
Follow me ſirs, and my proceedings eye;
It is decreed, Heor the great muſt dye.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: The Cuckold and the Cuckold maker are at it:
now bull, now dogge, lowe; Paris lowe; now my dou —
ble hen’d ſparrow; lowe Paris, lowe; the bull has the
game: ware hornes ho?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Turne ſlaue and fight.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: What art thou?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: A Baſtard Sonne of Priams.

speech.speaker: Ther.
speech.line: I am a Baſtard too, I loue Baſtards, I am a Ba —
ſtard begot, Baſtard inſtrued, Baſtard in minde, Baſtard
in valour, in euery thing illegitimate: one Beare will not
bite another, and wherefore ſhould one Baſtard? take
heede, the quarrel’s moſt ominous to vs: if the Sonne of a
whore fight for a whore, he tempts iudgement: farewell
Baſtard.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: The diuell take thee coward.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: Moſt putrified core ſo faire without:
Thy goodly armour thus hath coſt thy life.
Now is my daies worke done; Ile take good breath:
Reſt Sword, thou haſt thy fill of bloud and death.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Looke Heor how the Sunne begins to ſet;
How vgly night comes breathing at his heeles,
Euen with the vaile and darking of the Sunne.
To cloſe the day vp, Heors life is done.

speech.speaker: He.
speech.line: I am vnarm’d, forgoe this vantage Greeke.

speech.speaker: Achil.
speech.line: Strike fellowes, ſtrike, this is the man I ſeeke.
So Illion fall thou: now Troy ſinke downe;
Here lyes thy heart, thy ſinewes, and thy bone.
On Myrmidons, cry you all a maine.
Achilles hath the mighty Heor ſlaine.
Harke, a retreat vpon our Grecian part.

speech.speaker: Gree.
speech.line: The Troian Trumpets ſounds the like my Lord.

speech.speaker: Achi.
speech.line: The dragon wing of night ore-ſpreds the earth
And ſtickler-like the Armies ſeperates
My halfe ſupt Sword, that frankly would haue fed,
Pleas’d with this dainty bed; thus goes to bed.
Come, tye his body to my horſes tayle;
Along the field, I will the Troian traile.

scene.stagedir: Enter Agamemnon, Aiax, Menelaus, Neſtor, Diomed, and the reſt marching.

speech.speaker: Aga.
speech.line: Harke, harke, what ſhout is that?

speech.speaker: Neſt.
speech.line: Peace Drums.

speech.speaker: Sold.
speech.line: Achilles, Achilles, Heor’s ſlaine, Achilles.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: The bruite is, Heor’s ſlaine, and by Achilles.

speech.speaker: Aia.
speech.line: If it be ſo, yet bragleſſe let it be:
Great Heor was a man as good as he.

speech.speaker: Agam.
speech.line: March patiently along: let one be ſent
To pray Achilles ſee vs at our Tent.
If in his death the gods haue vs befrended,
Great Troy is ours, and our ſharpe wars are ended.

scene.stagedir: Enter Æneas, Paris, Anthenor and Deiphœbus.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: Stand hoe, yet are we maiſters of the field,
Neuer goe home; here ſtarue we out the night.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Heor is ſlaine.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Heor? the gods forbid.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Hee’s dead: and at the murtherers Horſes taile,
In beaſtly ſort, drag’d through the ſhamefull Field.
Frowne on you heauens, effe your rage with ſpeede:
Sit gods vpon your throanes, and ſmile at Troy.
I ſay at once, let your briefe plagues be mercy,
And linger not our ſure deſtruions on.

speech.speaker: Æne.
speech.line: My Lord, you doe diſcomfort all the Hoſte.

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: You vnderſtand me not, that tell me ſo:
I doe not ſpeake of flight, of feare, of death,
But dare all imminence that gods and men,
Addreſſe their dangers in. Heor is gone:
Who ſhall tell Priam ſo? or Hecuba?
Let him that will a ſcreechoule aye be call’d,
Goe in to Troy, and ſay there, Heor’s dead:
There is a word will Priam turne to ſtone;
Make wels, and Niobes of the maides and wiues;
Coole ſtatues of the youth: and in a word,
Scarre Troy out of it ſelfe. But march away,
Heor is dead: there is no more to ſay.
Stay yet: you vile abhominable Tents,
Thus proudly pight vpon our Phrygian plaines:
Let Titan riſe as early as he dare,
Ile through, and through you; & thou great ſiz’d coward:
No ſpace of Earth ſhall ſunder our two hates,
Ile haunt thee, like a wicked conſcience ſtill,
That mouldeth goblins ſwift as frenſies thoughts.
Strike a free march to Troy, with comfort goe:
Hope of reuenge, ſhall hide our inward woe.

speech.speaker: Pand.
speech.line: But heare you? heare you?

speech.speaker: Troy.
speech.line: Hence broker, lackie, ignomy, and ſhame
Purſue thy life, and liue aye with thy name.

speech.speaker: Pan.
speech.line: A goodly medcine for mine aking bones: oh world,
world, world! thus is the poore agent diſpiſde: Oh trai —
tours and bawdes; how earneſtly are you ſet aworke, and
how ill requited? why ſhould our indeuour be ſo deſir’d,
and the performance ſo loath’d? What Verſe for it? what
inſtance for it? let me ſee.
Full merrily the humble Bee doth ſing,
Till he hath loſt his hony, and his ſting.
And being once ſubdu’d in armed taile,
Sweete hony, and ſweete notes together faile.
Good traders in the fleſh, ſet this in your painted cloathes;
As many as be here of Panders hall,
Your eyes halfe out, weepe out at Pandar’s fall:
Or if you cannot weepe, yet giue ſome grones;
Though not for me, yet for your aking bones:
Brethren and ſiſters of the hold-dore trade,
Some two months hence, my will ſhall here be made:
It ſhould be now, but that my feare is this:
Some galled Gooſe of Wincheſter would hiſſe:
Till then, Ile ſweate, and ſeeke about for eaſes;
And at that time bequeath you my diſeaſes.
